Nothing herein contained shall preclude the council from using other available means of financing improvements, including federal or state grants-in-aid, sewer service or other types of service charges, revenue bonds, general obligation bonds, or other legal means of finance. In the event any of such other means of finance are used, the council may, in its discretion, levy special assessments hereunder according to benefits to cover any part of the costs of the improvement not covered by such means. 
(Ord. 1211-C § 9, 1956) 
3.12.100 - Appeal. 
    Any person feeling aggrieved by assessments made as herein provided may, within sixty (60) days from the passage of the ordinance levying the assessment by the council, appeal therefrom to the circuit court of the state of Oregon for Yamhill County. Such appeal and the requirements and formalities thereof shall be heard, governed and determined and the judgment thereon rendered and enforced so far as is practical in the manner provided for appeals from reassessments contained in ORS 223.005 to 223.105, and 223.205 to 223.930 as now or hereafter amended. The result of such appeal shall be a final and conclusive determination of the matter of such assessment, except with respect to the city's right of reassessment as provided herein. 
(Ord. 00-1 § l(i), 2000; Ord. 1211-C § 10, 1956) 
3.12.110 - Lien recording-Interest and foreclosure. 
    After the ordinance levying assessments has been passed, the city recorder shall enter in the docket of city liens a statement of the respective amounts assessed upon each particular lot, tract, or parcel of land with the names of the record owners thereof, and, so far as readily known, the names of the owners thereof as defined herein. Upon such entry in the lien docket, the amount so entered shall be a lien and charged upon the respective lots, tracts, and parcels of land against which the same are placed. Such liens shall be first and prior to all other liens or encumbrances thereon whatsoever insofar as the laws of the state of Oregon allow. Interest shall be charged at the rate of six percent per annum until paid on all amounts not paid within thirty (30) days from the date of such entry, or entry corrected pursuant to Section 3.12.130. The city may proceed to foreclose or enforce any lien to which it shall be entitled pursuant to the provisions of this chapter at any time after thirty (30) days from the date on which the assessment, or assessment corrected pursuant to Section 3.12.130, was entered in the lien docket, in the manner provided for the foreclosure or enforcement of liens by the general laws of the state. 
(Ord. 1211-C § 11, 1956) 
3.12.120 - Notice of assessment-Bonding. 
    Within ten (10) days after the ordinance levying assessments has been passed, the city recorder shall send by registered mail, to his or her last known address, a notice of assessment to the record owner and, so far as readily known, to the owner as herein defined, of each lot, tract, or parcel of land assessed. This notice shall state the time within which such assessments must be paid or bonded and that assessments which are not paid or bonded within the time stated in the notice shall bear interest at six percent per annum and that the property so assessed is subject to foreclosure if such assessments are not paid or bonded within the time stated in the notice. Such record owner or other owner as herein defined may make application to bond such assessment pursuant to the provisions of ORS 223.205 and 223.210 to 223.295, which is known as the "Bancroft Bonding Act," together with amendments or future amendments thereof. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(j), 2000; Ord. 1211-C § 12, 1956) 
3.12.130 - Errors in assessment calculations. 
    Claimed errors in the calculation of assessments shall be called to the attention of the city recorder prior to any payment on account thereof. Said city recorder shall determine whether there is an error in fact. If the city recorder shall find that there is an error in fact, he or she shall recommend to the council an amendment to the assessment ordinance to correct the error. Upon the enactment of such an amendment by the council, the city recorder shall make the necessary correction in the docket of city liens and send by registered mail to the last known address of the owner a corrected notice of the assessment. 
(Ord. 1211-C § 13, 1956) 
3.12.140 - Deficit assessment. 
    If assessment is made before the total costs of the improvements are known, and it be found that the amount assessed is insufficient to defray the expenses of the improvement, the council may by motion declare such deficit and prepare a proposed deficit assessment. The council shall set a time for a hearing of objections to such deficit assessment and shall direct the city recorder to publish reasonable notice thereof in a newspaper of general circulation, printed and published in Sheridan. The council, upon such hearing, shall make a just and equitable deficit assessment by ordinance. Such deficit assessment shall be consolidated with the assessment in the lien docket in accordance with the provisions of Section 3.12.110. Thereafter, the provisions of Sections 3.12.120 and 3.12.130 shall be applicable with regard to such deficit assessment. 
(Ord. 1211-C § 14, 1956) 
3.12.150 - Rebate. 
    If, upon the completion of the project, it is found that any sum theretofore assessed therefor upon any property is more than sufficient to pay the cost thereof, the council must ascertain and declare the same by ordinance, and when so declared, it must be entered in the docket of city liens as a credit upon the appropriate assessment. If any such assessment has been paid, the person who paid the same, or his or her legal representative, shall be entitled to the payment of any portion of the rebate credit which exceeds the assessment, by a warrant on the city treasury. 
(Ord. 1211-C § 15, 1956) 
3.12.160 - Abandonment of proceedings. 
    The council shall have full power and authority to abandon and rescind proceedings for improvements hereunder at any time prior to the final consummation of such proceedings, and if liens have been assessed upon any property under this procedure, they shall be canceled, and any payments made thereon shall be refunded to the payor, his or her assigns, or legal representatives. 
(Ord. 1211-C § 16, 1956) 
3.12.170 - Curative provisions. 
    No improvement assessment shall be invalid by reason of a failure to give, in any report, in the proposed assessment, in the assessment ordinance or ordinances, in the lien docket or elsewhere in the proceedings, the name of the owner of any lot, tract, or parcel of land or part thereof or the name of any person having a lien upon or interest in such property, or by reason of any error, mistake, delay, omission, irregularity, or other act, jurisdictional or otherwise, in any of the proceedings or steps hereinabove specified, unless it appears that the assessment as made, insofar as it affects the person complaining, is unfair and unjust, and the council shall have power and authority to remedy and correct all such matters by suitable action and proceedings. 
(Ord. 1211-C § 17, 1956) 
3.12.180 - Reassessment. 
    Whenever an assessment, deficit assessment, or reassessment for any improvement which has been or may be hereafter made by the city has been or shall be hereafter set aside, annulled, declared or rendered void, or its enforcement refuted by any court of this state or any federal court having jurisdiction thereof, whether directly or by virtue of any decision of such court, or when the council shall be in doubt as to the validity of such assessment, deficit assessment, or reassessment or any part thereof, the council may make a new assessment or reassessment. Such reassessments shall be made in the manner provided by ORS 223.405 to 223.485 as now or hereafter amended. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(k), 2000; Ord. 1211-C § 18, 1956) 
Title 5 - BUSINESS LICENSES AND REGULATIONS 
Chapter 5.04 - CLOSING OUT SALES AND SIMILAR SALES 

5.04.010 - Closing out sales-License required. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to advertise or conduct any sale of goods, wares or merchandise at retail that is represented as a bankrupt, insolvent, assignee's, adjuster's, trustee's, executor's, administrator's, receiver's, wholesaler's, jobber's, manufacturer's, closing out, liquidation, closing stock, fire or water damage sale, or any other sale which is by representation or advertisement intended to lead the public to believe that the person conducting such sale is selling out or closing out the goods, wares or merchandise of any business or any designated portion or line of goods therein for less than the current or going retail price thereof in the city, without first filing with the city council the inventory hereinafter provided for and obtaining from the city council a license so to do, to be known as a closing out sale license. 
B.  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or association to bring into the city any goods, wares or merchandise for the purpose of selling the same at retail at any sale as designated in subsection A of this section. No license shall be granted to any person, firm, corporation or association to conduct a sale of any such goods, wares or merchandise under any sale as set forth in subsection A of this section, unless such goods, wares and merchandise have been a bona fide part of a regular stock of merchandise of a person, firm, corporation or association engaged in regular business within the city. 
C.  No license shall be issued for any of said sales defined in subsection A of this section unless it shall appear that the property proposed to be sold is or was a bona fide part of a stock-in-trade of a merchant in business in the city and that the sale to be conducted is in fact of the nature advertised, and that said stock in trade was not secured, purchased, or brought into said place of business for or in anticipation of such sale. It is unlawful for any person during the progress of such sale to replenish his or her stock by substitutions, fill-ins, leaders, or goods of any character whatsoever. 
(Ord. 1088 §§ 1 and 2, 1941) 
5.04.020 - Transient merchant's sales-License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to sell or advertise or offer for sale at retail any stock of goods, wares or merchandise brought to the city for the purpose of disposal at any sale represented as a bankrupt, insolvent, assignee's, adjuster's, trustee's, executor's, administrator's, receiver's, wholesaler's, jobber's, manufacturer's, closing out, liquidation, closing stock, fire or water damage sale, or any other sale which by representation or advertisement is intended to lead the public to believe that the person conducting such sale is closing out said stock of goods for less than the current or going retail price thereof in the city without first filing with the city council the inventory hereinafter provided for and obtaining from the city council a license so to do, to be known as a transient merchant's sales license. 
(Ord. 1088 § 3, 1941) 
5.04.030 - Application for license. 
    Not less than fifteen (15) days previous to conducting any such sale as provided in Sections 5.04.010 and 5.04.020, the said persons, firms, corporations or associations must make a sworn, written application to the council of the city for a license so to do, specifying under oath the name and address of the applicant, and the location and purpose of the sale, and its expected duration, and itemizing in detail the quality, quantity, kind and grade of each item of goods, wares and other articles to be sold, the wholesale market value thereof, and the name of the person, firm, corporation or association who shall conduct the said sale. 
(Ord. 1088 § 4, 1941) 
5.04.040 - Commencement of sale-Fraud. 
    All sales as defined in Sections 5.04.010 and 5.04.020 shall be held on successive days, Sundays and legal holidays excepted, and shall not continue for more than ninety (90) days in all from the commencement of said sale. Any false or fraudulent statement or representation made by any applicant for the purpose of procuring a license shall be deemed to be a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1088 § 5, 1941) 
5.04.050 - Bond. 
    Every applicant for license as provided in Sections 5.04.010 and 5.04.020 shall tender with said application a good and sufficient surety bond in the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00), conditioned upon the observance of the provisions of this chapter, and for the indemnification of any purchaser at any of the said sales as defined in Sections 5.04.010 and 5.04.020 in suffering a loss by reason of fraud or misrepresentation in the sale of any article as herein defined. 
(Ord. 1088 § 6, 1941) 
5.04.060 - Transfer of license prohibited-Revocation. 
    The licenses granted under this chapter shall not be transferable and may be revoked by the council for fraud or misrepresentation in the application for license or in the conduct of such sale. 
(Ord. 1088 § 7, 1941) 
5.04.070 - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any sales held for charitable or benevolent purposes, or for any church fair, festival or bazaar where substantially the entire proceeds of such sale shall be devoted to such purpose. 
(Ord. 1088 § 8, 1941) 
5.04.080 - License fees. 
A.  The license fees for any of the sales as defined in Section 5.04.010 shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
B.  The license fees for any of the sales as defined in Section 5.04.020 shall be as follows: 
1. For stock of goods, wares and merchandise at $1,000.00 or less $25.00 2. For stock of goods, wares and merchandise at not more than $10,000.00 and more than $1,000.00 50.00 3. For stock of goods, wares and merchandise at more than $10,000.00 100.00  
(Ord. 1088 § 10, 1941) 
5.04.090 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.  A person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall: 
1.  Upon the first conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00); 
2.  Upon the second conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00); 
3.  Upon the third or further conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. 
B.  Each day's violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense, punishable as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. 88-3 (part), 1988; Ord. 1088 § 11, 1941) 
Chapter 5.08 - COIN-OPERATED MUSIC DEVICES 

5.08.010 - License required. 
    It is declared unlawful for any person to display in any public or private place of amusement or business in the city, a coin-in-the-slot-operated mechanical device which is designed to provide music unless a license has been obtained therefor. 
(Ord. 49-7 § 1, 1949) 
5.08.020 - Application. 
    Any person desiring to obtain a license for such coin-in-the-slot-operated mechanical device designed to provide music shall apply to the city recorder for a license. The city recorder shall furnish application blanks which shall be filled in by the applicant stating the number of such devices to be licensed, the premises where located, a brief description of each device, and sign the application. 
(Ord. 49-7 § 2, 1949) 
5.08.030 - License fee. 
    The license fee for each coin-in-the-slot-operated mechanical device as set forth in Section 5.08.020 shall be five dollars ($5.00) per annum beginning with the first day of August, 1949. 
(Ord. 49-7 § 3, 1949) 
5.08.040 - Issuance of license. 
    Upon the payment of the said five dollars ($5.00) and the filing of said application with the city recorder, the city recorder shall issue a license. If such applicant shall apply for a license for more than one of such devices, then the sum of five dollars ($5.00) shall be collected for each of such devices. 
(Ord. 49-7 § 4, 1949) 
5.08.050 - Transfer of license prohibited. 
    Such licenses shall not be transferable as between persons or from one of such devices to another. 
(Ord. 49-7 § 5, 1949) 
5.08.060 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.  A person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall: 
1.  Upon the first conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00); 
2.  Upon the second conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00); 
3.  Upon the third or further conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. 
B.  Each day's violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense, punishable as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. 88-3 (part), 1988; Ord. 49-7 § 6, 1949) 
Chapter 5.12 - GAMBLING GAMES* 

5.12.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the regulation of social games as provided in ORS 167.121. Said regulations are intended to ensure compliance with state statutes, to keep wagering within reasonable limits, and to provide rules under which players can participate on an equal basis and where no person profits from the games, except as a player. 
(Ord. 83-3 § 1, 1983) 
5.12.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, except where the context indicates otherwise: 
    "Card room" means any space, room or enclosure in which social games are intended to be played. 
    "Contest of chance" means any contest, game, gaming scheme or gaming device in which the outcome depends in a material degree upon an element of chance, notwithstanding that the skill of contestants may also be a factor therein, and in which a person stakes or risks something of value upon the outcome of a future contingent event not under his or her control or influence, upon an agreement or understanding that the contestant or someone else will receive something of value in the event of a certain outcome. 
    "House" means any person, organization, corporation or business other than a player. 
    "Player" means a person who engages in any form of gambling solely as a contestant or bettor, without receiving or becoming entitled to receive any profit therefrom other than personal gambling winnings, and without otherwise rendering any material assistance to the establishment, conduct or operation of the particular gambling activity. A person who gambles at a social game of chance on equal terms with the other participants therein is a person who does not otherwise render material assistance to the establishment, conduct or operation thereof. A person who engages in bookmaking is not a player. 
    "Social game" mean a contest of chance involving the playing of cards only, which does not include lotteries and any kind of game using dice, between players in a private business, private club, or a place of public accommodation where no house player, house bank or house odds exist and there is no house income from the operation of the social game. 
(Ord. 83-3 § 2, 1983) 
5.12.030 - Card room licenses. 
A.  No person, entity, corporation or business shall engage in or carry on, or maintain, conduct or cause to be engaged in, carried on, maintained or conducted, any card room where social games are conducted without having a valid license from the city. 
B.  An application for a card room license shall be submitted to the city recorder, which application shall be under oath and shall include, among other things, the true names and addresses of all persons financially interested in the business; the personal history and business experiences of such persons; the past criminal record, if any, of all persons who have any interest in the business; and any other matters deemed by the council to be of necessary inquiry. Said application shall also be accompanied by a sixty-five dollar ($65.00) nonrefundable investigation fee. The term "person financially interested" shall include all persons who share in the profits of the business on the basis of gross or net revenue, including landlords, lessors, lessees, and the owner or owners of the building, fixtures or equipment. The application shall also be accompanied by fingerprints and photographs of persons financially interested. 
C.  A card room license shall be issued in the name of the owner, proprietor or lessee of the premises for which the permit is sought, and is applicable only to those premises. The license must be posted in plain sight of the general public. 
D.  Such licenses shall be granted only upon the approval of the city council. 
E.  Such license shall not be granted if: 
1.  Any person financially interested in the business has been previously convicted of a felony within the last ten (10) years; 
2.  Any person financially interested in the business has been convicted of any crime involving gambling within the last five years; 
3.  The applicant has knowingly or wilfully supplied false or misleading information in the application; 
4.  Any person financially interested in the business has had a license, which was in his or her name, revoked or suspended three or more times by the Oregon Liquor Control Commission, the last of which was in the last three years; 
5.  Any person financially interested in the business has violated any section of this chapter; or 
6.  Any person financially interested in the business has been convicted of an offense involving moral turpitude within the last five years. 
F.  No license issued pursuant to this section shall be assignable or transferable. The addition or the substitution of a person financially interested in a licensed business shall be reported immediately to the city council via the chief of police. 
G.  Licenses may only be granted to individuals, entities or corporations who possess a current, unsuspended license from the Oregon Liquor Control Commission to sell alcoholic beverages on the premises. 
H.  There shall be collected for each card room licensed hereunder, except as provided in subsection I of this section, a fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per table per year. The annual fee is payable on or before January 1st of each year and shall be prorated for licenses acquired during the calendar year. 
I.  A nonprofit society, club or fraternal organization having adopted bylaws and duly elected directors and members may be granted a card room license at an annual fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year when it appears that the tables are for the exclusive use of members of the society, club or fraternal organization, no charge is made for participation, and the conduct of social games is not the primary reason for existence of the society, club or fraternal organization. The society, club or fraternal organization shall have been in continuous existence, actively conducting its affairs in the jurisdiction covered by this chapter, for a period of two years immediately preceding application for a license. The annual fee is payable on or before January 1st of each year and shall be prorated for licenses acquired during the calendar year. 
(Ord. 83-3 § 3, 1983) 
5.12.040 - Advertising. 
    No licensee shall advertise or otherwise promote the playing of social games other than by providing, without fee or remuneration, the use of premises and supplying cards or other equipment used therein. 
(Ord. 83-3 § 4, 1983) 
5.12.050 - Regulations. 
A.  All card rooms shall be open to police inspection during all hours of operation. Doors leading into card rooms must remain unlocked during all hours of operation. Hours of operation shall be the same as Oregon Liquor Control Commission serving hours. 
B.  Each licensee hereunder shall provide reasonable supervision of the games and see to it that they are played strictly in accordance with this chapter and within the provisions of the Oregon Revised Statutes. 
C.  The playing of all card games, shall be so arranged as to provide equal access and visibility to any interested party. 
D.  No person under the age of twenty-one (21) shall be permitted to participate in any card game. 
E.  No charge shall be collected from any player for the privilege of participating in any game. 
F.  In games of "blackjack" or "21" or any other game where the probability of a dealer winning is greater than the probability of other players winning, the deal must rotate to the holder of a "blackjack" or any two cards totaling twenty-one (21). The deal cannot be purchased and shall be passed to the next player on the left should a player be unable or unwilling to deal. In the alternative, a licensee may adopt a rule providing that the deal shall always be passed to the next person on the left at regular intervals, up to every fifth hand. No person shall be required to display or otherwise have in his or her possession a minimum quantity of money or chips in order to become the dealer. A player in the game of "blackjack" or "21" shall be limited to playing of one hand. 
G.  There shall be a limit on any bet of three dollars ($3.00) and a limit of three raises, except games described in subsection F of this section where there shall be a limit on any bet of five dollars ($5.00). There shall be no raises in games described in subsection F of this section. 
H.  No participant in any social game shall be charged a price for any consumer goods which is higher or lower than the price charged nonparticipants. 
I.  All players must participate on an equal basis. 
J.  There shall be no nonplaying dealers or other nonplaying participants. 
K.  There shall be no profits, tips or other gratuity given to a dealer or other player, except ordinary winnings. 
L.  The deal cannot be purchased. If the dealer cannot or is unwilling to deal, the deal shall pass to the next player on the left. 
M.  A copy of the regulations set out in this section shall be posted in a conspicuous place by the card room licensee in all areas where social games are played. 
(Ord. 85-4, 1985; Ord. 83-3 § 5, 1983) 
5.12.060 - Suspension and revocation of licenses. 
A.  The chief of police may, with the approval of the city council, temporarily suspend any card room license issued hereunder, or the chief of police may apply for permanent revocation of any card room license issued hereunder if: 
1.  Any licensee hereunder shall fail to meet the requirements of Section 5.12.030; or 
2.  Any licensee hereunder violates Section 5.12.040 with respect to the licensee's card room; or 
3.  Any person having control or right of control over premises licensed under this chapter permits unlawful gambling to occur or otherwise fails to prevent the occurrence or continuation of games that are in violation of Section 5.12.050. 
B.  Any temporary suspension shall be for a period of up to thirty (30) days, and shall be effective one hour after notice is served upon a person in control or with right of control over premises licensed by this chapter. 
C.  Permanent revocation may be made by the city council and such revocation shall take place at a public hearing, and only after the licensee has been personally served with written notice at least ten (10) days prior to said public hearing. Such notice shall include the time, date and place of the public hearing and the grounds upon which the permanent revocation is sought. 
(Ord. 83-3 § 6, 1983) 
5.12.070 - Existing card rooms. 
    Licensed card rooms and their employees in existence at the date of the adoption of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall not be required to pay the investigation fee established by Section 5.12.030 in order to obtain permits pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. 83-3 § 7, 1983) 
Chapter 5.16 - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, AUCTIONEERS, CIRCUSES AND GAME OPERATORS 

5.16.010 - Auctioneers. 
    Every person who, as principal or agent, shall offer at public outcry for sale to the highest bidder any article of merchandise or property shall be deemed an auctioneer. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to act as an auctioneer within the corporate limits of the city without first having obtained a license as hereinafter provided. 
B.  The provisions of this section, however, shall not apply to judicial or executive officers making auction sales by virtue of a decree of any court, or to public sales by executors and administrators of property of estates. 
(Ord. 1087 § 1, 1941) 
5.16.020 - Peddlers and hawkers. 
A.  Definitions. As used in this section: 
    "Hawker" means any person who, for himself or herself or as agent of another, carries, offers, or exposes for sale any goods, wares, merchandise, produce, or any article or thing for which a price is asked in or on the streets to customers in or on the streets, or who offers or exposes for sale any such commodity from a doorway, recess, alleyway, vacant lot, or other place facing on a street, whether making outcry or not. 
    "Peddler" means any person who, for himself or herself or as agent for another, goes from place to place or from house to house within the city of Sheridan carrying, offering, or exposing for sale any goods, wares, merchandise or produce, or any article or thing for which a price is asked. 
    "Retail" means any sale direct to the consumer or user for consumption or use and not for resale purposes. 
B.  License Required. It is unlawful for any person, either for himself or herself or as agent of another, to peddle, to hawk, or to engage in the business or occupation of peddling or hawking within the city without first securing a license so to do. 
C.  License Classifications. 
1.  For license purposes, peddlers shall be classified as follows: 
    Class 1: Those using a vehicle in peddling. 
    Class 2: Those peddling on foot. 
2.  For license purposes, hawkers shall be classified as follows: 
    Class 1: Hawkers of patent medicines who use music or other devices to attract attention. 
    Class 2: Hawkers of patent medicines not included in Class 1. 
    Class 3: Hawkers of goods, wares, merchandise or commodities other than patent medicine who sell at retail while traveling from place to place within the city, or from a stand or vehicle upon any street, alley, highway, or public or private grounds within the limits of the city. 
D.  Separate Licenses Required. Whenever more than one person shall sell or offer to sell from the same stand or wagon, each of said persons shall be required to take out the license hereinafter required. 
E.  Exceptions. Peddlers or hawkers who distribute newspapers or bibles or products of the farm raised by themselves shall not be subject to payment of any license fee. 
(Ord. 1087 § 2, 1941) 
5.16.030 - Solicitors. 
    A "solicitor" is defined as any person who goes from house to house or from place to place in the city of Sheridan selling or taking orders for, or offering to sell or take orders for, goods, wares or merchandise or any article for future delivery, or for services to be performed in the future, or for the making, manufacturing or repairing of any article or thing whatsoever for future delivery, excepting goods, wares and merchandise involved in interstate commerce. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to act as a solicitor within the meaning and application of this section without first securing a license from the city recorder of the city of Sheridan. 
B.  All orders taken by licensed solicitors shall be written in duplicate, stating the terms thereof, and the amount paid in advance, if any. One copy shall be given to the purchaser. 
(Ord. 1087 § 3, 1941) 
5.16.040 - Circuses, carnivals, or operatic or mechanical shows under canvas or in open space or area. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to give or conduct any circus, carnival, or operatic or mechanical show under canvas or in an open space or area within the city limits of the city where the patronage of the public is solicited and an admission fee is charged or collected, without first having obtained a license so to do as hereinafter provided. 
B.  This chapter shall not apply to any entertainment, show or program, the entire proceeds of which go to some church, school, band, or civic organization existing for the benefit of the whole community. 
(Ord. 1087 § 4, 1941) 
5.16.050 - Games. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to operate any games of skill for hire or revenue without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Ord. 1087 § 5, 1941) 
5.16.060 - Licenses. 
    The licenses provided for in this chapter shall be issued by the city recorder and are not transferable. Such licenses are subject to revocation by the council at any time for violation of the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city. There shall be no refund on licenses which have been so revoked. 
(Ord. 1087 § 6, 1941) 
5.16.070 - Schedule of fees. 
    License fees shall be as follows: 
Auctioneers $25.00 per day* Circuses, carnivals and operatic or mechanical shows 50.00 per day* Peddlers Class 1 5.00 per day* Class 2 3.00 per day* Hawkers Class 1 5.00 per day* Class 2 3.00 per day* Class 3 3.00 per day, or $30.00 for a 90-day license* Games, each game operated for hire or revenue 3.00 per month* Solicitors 3.00 per day  
* During those days known as "Phil Sheridan Days" within the city of Sheridan, the schedule of fees set forth above for auctioneers, circuses, peddlers and hawkers shall be charged not on a per-day basis but on a per-event basis. The charge for a license fee to auctioneers, circuses, carnivals, operatic and mechanical shows, peddlers and hawkers shall be the sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00), which permit and license fee shall be effective for the entire duration of said "Phil Sheridan Days" special event. 
(Ord. 94-4 § 1, 1994: Ord. 88-16 (part), 1988; Ord. 1087 § 7, 1941) 
5.16.080 - Charitable organizations. 
    The fee provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any street hawker, auctioneer or circus or carnival operator which shall have paid the required fee for selling its wares or providing its services charged by a charitable nonprofit organization which has its principal place of business or principal offices located within the city limits of the city of Sheridan, Oregon. Such exemption shall be limited to hawkers, auctioneers, or circus or carnival operators who are maintaining their operations in connection with a local charitable organization which has obtained advance approval from the city council of a specified event, including approval of its fee structure, rules and regulations, and which charitable organization has agreed to pay any charge, deposit, or other fees which may be established by the city council to cover the reasonable costs incurred by the city in connection with such event. 
(Ord. 88-11, 1988; Ord. 88-3 (part), 1988; Ord. 1087 § 8, 1941) 
5.16.090 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.  A person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall: 
1.  Upon the first conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00); 
2.  Upon the second conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00); 
3.  Upon the third or further conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. 
B.  Each day's violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense, punishable as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. 88-16 (part), 1988: Ord. 1087 § 9, 1941) 
Chapter 5.20 - POPCORN AND PEANUT VENDORS 

5.20.010 - License required. 
    Any person or persons selling or offering to sell popcorn and peanuts from a vehicle or stand located on the streets of the city shall first obtain a license as herein provided. 
(Ord. 48-11 § 1, 1948) 
5.20.020 - Application. 
    Any person or persons desiring to operate a popcorn wagon or sell popcorn and peanuts from a vehicle or stand located in the streets of the city shall apply directly to the city council of said city requesting that a license be granted for such purpose. 
(Ord. 48-11 § 2, 1948) 
5.20.030 - Determination of available parking space. 
    The city council shall determine whether there is sufficient parking places on the streets of the city to park such vehicle or stand. If the city council shall determine that there is sufficient parking available then the council shall determine the place or places where such stand or vehicle may be parked and the time or hours of the day such stand or vehicle may be parked at such place or places. 
(Ord. 48-11 § 3, 1948) 
5.20.040 - License fee-Issuance. 
    If the council shall determine that there is available parking places as in Section 5.20.030, then upon the payment of the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) to the city recorder a license shall issue to the applicant for a period of one year, stating in said license the place or places available for parking in the city streets and the hours of each day that said vehicle or stand may be parked at such place or places. 
(Ord. 48-11 § 4, 1948) 
5.20.050 - Revocation. 
    In the event the licensee shall violate any of the terms of his or her license, then the city council may revoke such license and the city retain the full amount of the license fee paid. 
(Ord. 48-11 § 5, 1948) 
5.20.060 - Denial of license. 
    In the event the city council shall determine that there is a shortage of parking space in the city and that the available parking space is needed for the parking of passenger cars and trucks, then the city council shall deny such license. 
(Ord. 48-11 § 6, 1948) 
5.20.070 - Unlawful conduct. 
    It is unlawful to operate a popcorn wagon or sell or attempt to sell popcorn, or peanuts, or other merchandise from a vehicle or stand situated upon any part or portion of the streets of the city without first obtaining a license from the city. 
(Ord. 48-11 § 7, 1948) 
5.20.080 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.  A person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall: 
1.  Upon the first conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00); 
2.  Upon the second conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00); 
3.  Upon the third or further conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. 
B.  Each day's violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense, punishable as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. 88-3 (part), 1988; Ord. 48-11 § 8, 1948) 
Chapter 5.24 - PUBLIC DANCES 

5.24.010 - Definition. 
    A public dance within the meaning of this chapter shall be held to include any dance for which compensation is paid directly or indirectly to the owner, proprietor, manager, lessee or operator, or other person or persons in charge thereof, by the dancers or by some other person or organization on their behalf, and such term "public dance" shall be construed to include all such dances, whether held in a dance hall or other building or whether held outside of a building. 
(Ord. 612-A § 6, 1948) 
5.24.020 - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons and their agents and employees, or for any company, corporation or fraternal organization and their officers, to operate or conduct any public dance, as described in this chapter, without first having paid for and obtained a license from the city. 
(Ord. 612-A § 1, 1948) 
5.24.030 - License fee. 
    A license fee of five dollars ($5.00) shall be charged for each and every public dance, which fee shall be paid to the city recorder of the city and such license issued prior to the time of the commencement of any dance of a public nature as defined in Section 5.24.010. 
(Ord. 612-A § 2, 1948) 
5.24.040 - Separate licenses and fees required-Hours of operation. 
    Such license fee of five dollars ($5.00) shall allow the licensee to operate a public dance from one p.m. to twelve midnight of the same day; a separate license shall be obtained and a separate fee as herein provided shall be paid for each and every public dance that is held, and prior to the commencement thereof. 
(Ord. 612-A § 3, 1948) 
5.24.050 - License contents-Posting. 
    The said license shall state thereon to whom it is issued, the place where the dance is to be held, the day such license is issued, and the date that such license is valid, and such further information that the city council may desire. The licensee shall post said license in a conspicuous place in the dance hall and as near the main entrance of the dance hall as practical. 
(Ord. 612-A § 4, 1948) 
5.24.060 - Acceptance deemed consent for entry. 
    Any applicant for a dance hall license shall be deemed, upon acceptance of such license, to operate a public dance, to consent as long as such license is valid to any duly appointed police officer of the city to enter such licensed premises at any time without cost or charge for the purpose of determining whether such dance is being conducted according to the ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. 612-A § 5, 1948) 
5.24.070 - Prohibited conduct. 
    All persons are prohibited from dancing in a disorderly manner and from being drunk or intoxicated in or about the place where the dance is being conducted, and if the person or organization to whom the license was issued shall fail to conduct the dance according to the laws of the city or shall allow persons upon the dance hall premises who are drunk or intoxicated, or who shall be loud and boisterous, or who shall fight or be engaged in disorderly conduct, then the city council has full and complete authority to deny such person or persons or organization a license to conduct a public dance or to revoke any license that may have been issued to such person or organization for conducting a public dance. 
(Ord. 612-A § 7, 1948) 
5.24.080 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.  A person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall: 
1.  Upon the first conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00); 
2.  Upon the second conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00); 
3.  Upon the third or further conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. 
B.  Each day's violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense, punishable as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. 88-3 (part), 1988; Ord. 612-A § 8, 1948) 
Chapter 5.28 - SKATING RINKS, SHOOTING GALLERIES, BOWLING ALLEYS, POOLROOMS AND SHUFFLEBOARD GAMES 

5.28.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Amusement device" means any machine or device designed to be operated or used for amusement or for playing a game upon the insertion of a coin or anything representing a coin, which does not vend or deliver any article or prize of value. 
    "Arcade" means a business or establishment with its principal purpose of providing the people with amusement devices for entertainment, including but not limited to pool tables and all coin-operated machines. The license fee provided in Section 5.28.030 shall include any and all fees which would otherwise be required for each amusement device. 
    "Bowling alley" means any place having a plane surface where balls are rolled for the purpose of knocking down pins and playing the game known as "bowling." 
    "Poolroom" or "billiard room" means any place where one or more pool or billiard tables are maintained for the use of the general public, whether an admission price or charge for the use of said tables is made or not. 
    "Shooting gallery" means any place or building where guns or pistols are kept and used for shooting targets, open to the general public, whether an admission price is charged or not. 
    "Shuffleboard" means sliding a metal puck on a plane surface but not to slide it off the plane surface and playing the same known as the game of "shuffleboard." 
    "Skating rink" means any place where the general public is admitted for the purpose of roller skating, whether a charge is made for the admission for the privilege of skating or not. 
(Ord. 72-11 § 1, 1972; Ord. 67-6 § 1, 1967) 
5.28.020 - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to operate within the city any arcade, skating rink, shooting gallery, bowling alley, pool or billiard rooms, or amusement device or shuffleboard, without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Ord. 72-11 § 2, 1972; Ord. 67-6 § 2, 1967) 
5.28.030 - Application. 
    Such licenses shall be issued upon application to the city recorder and the payment of the license fee in the amount hereinafter set forth. All such licenses shall run for a period of three months and concurrently with the quarters of the calendar year commencing with January 1st of each year, except that licenses issued during any quarter shall be prorated as to fee from the date of issue and shall expire at the end of the quarter in which issued. The quarterly license fees shall be due and payable on January 1st, April 1st, July 1st, and October 1st of each year. The license issued under the terms of this chapter may be revoked by the city council at any time for the violation by the licensee of any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 67-6 § 3, 1967) 
5.28.040 - Fees. 
    The license fees shall be as follows: 
Skating rinks $ 5.00 per quarter Shooting galleries 10.00 per quarter Bowling alleys, per alley 6.00 per quarter Pool or billiard rooms, per table 4.00 per quarter Amusement devices 3.00 per quarter Shuffleboards, per board 4.00 per quarter Arcade (up to 20 devices) 30.00 per quarter Arcade (from 21 to 60 devices) 90.00 per quarter Arcade (more than 60 devices) 200.00 per quarter  
(Ord. 05-3 § 1, 2005: Ord. 72-11 § 4 (part), 1972; Ord. 67-6 § 4, 1967) 
5.28.050 - Hours of operation. 
    No skating rink shall be operated after eleven p.m. or before seven a.m. of any week day; nor from one a.m. to twelve noon on Sunday. No arcade, shooting gallery, bowling alley, pool or billiard room, or shuffleboard shall be operated from two a.m. to six a.m. on any week day, nor from two a.m. to twelve noon on Sunday. 
(Ord. 72-11 § 4 (part), 1972; Ord. 67-6 § 5, 1967) 
5.28.060 - Gambling and intoxicated persons prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for the owner or operator of any arcade, skating rink, shooting gallery, bowling alley, poolroom, billiard room, amusement device or shuffleboard, his or her agents or employees, to permit any form of gambling therein, or to permit any person under the influence of intoxicating liquor in such room or place. 
(Ord. 72-11 § 5, 1972; Ord. 67-6 § 6, 1967) 
5.28.070 - Discharge of firearms in shooting galleries. 
    No person shall discharge any firearms in any shooting gallery when the noise resulting therefrom can be heard over a distance of three hundred (300) feet from such shooting gallery, and such shooting galleries must be enclosed in such a manner that persons on the outside thereof shall not be endangered or annoyed by the discharge of firearms therein. The owner or operator of the shooting gallery shall be responsible for any violations of this section if such happens upon premises subject to his or her control. 
(Ord. 67-6 § 7, 1967) 
5.28.080 - Posting of sticker or label on premises required. 
    The licenses required by this chapter shall be issued by the city recorder upon applications furnished by the city recorder, which applications shall contain the name and address of the applicant, the purpose for which the license is applied, the name and address of the place where the amusement device, pool or billiard room, arcade, bowling alley, shooting gallery, skating rink or shuffleboard is located and, in the case of an amusement device, the general description of the device and the identification numbers of the device, together with such other information as the council may require; and upon the payment of the license fee herein required, the city recorder shall issue a sticker or label upon which shall be written or printed the words, "City of Sheridan, Oregon, License," the date of issue, the purpose for which issued, the name and the address of the licensee, and the signature of the city recorder. The sticker or label shall be securely affixed to the amusement device for which issued, in plain sight; the license for a skating rink, shooting gallery, arcade, bowling alley, poolroom, billiard room and shuffleboard shall be posted in a conspicuous place inside the building where such activity is carried on. 
(Ord. 72-11 § 6, 1972; Ord. 67-6 § 8, 1967) 
5.28.090 - Minors on premises. 
    No person operating, maintaining or engaging in an affected business having a fixed place of business within the city limits of Sheridan who knows, or in the exercise of reasonable care should know, that one or more of the following conditions exists, shall permit any minor: 
A.  To possess, consume, or be upon the premises while under the influence of alcoholic liquor, narcotics or dangerous drugs; 
B.  To resort to the premises for purposes of truancy. 
(Ord. 81-7 (part), 1981; Ord. 67-6 § 9, 1967) 
5.28.100 - Inspection. 
    The chief of police of the city shall inspect each amusement device, arcade, skating rink, shooting gallery, bowling alley, poolroom, billiard room and shuffleboard to see if the same are properly licensed. Such inspection shall be made at least once each quarter. 
(Ord. 81-7 (part), 1981; Ord. 72-11 § 7, 1972; Ord. 67-6 § 11, 1967) 
5.28.110 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.  A person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall: 
1.  Upon the first conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00); 
2.  Upon the second conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00); 
3.  Upon the third or further conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. 
B.  Each day's violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense, punishable as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. 88-3, 1988; Ord. 81-7 (part), 1981; Ord. 67-6 § 13, 1967) 
Chapter 5.32 - SOLICITORS 

5.32.010 - Purpose. 
    The city council finds it necessary and desirable to regulate solicitation in order to provide an effective opportunity for the occupants of residential property to protect themselves from the unwanted disruption of the peaceful and quiet enjoyment of their property and right to privacy caused by solicitors, to protect the rights to free speech guaranteed by the Oregon and federal constitutions for lawful solicitors, and to provide a means by which those solicitors who choose to intrude upon and disrupt an occupant's quiet enjoyment of property can be held accountable for such violations. The city council has also been advised that based upon actual experiences in Sheridan and in the opinion of crime prevention specialists nationwide, there is a direct connection between residential burglaries and unscrupulous solicitors. The creation of a registration requirement will enable city officials and citizens of the city to become informed concerning the individuals and organizations who choose to solicit in the city. This chapter also provides a mechanism for discouraging, through the civil infraction process, those solicitors who avoid registration and provides a mechanism to identify and discourage those who would use solicitation as a front for criminal activity. 
(Ord. 89-5 § 1, 1989) 
5.32.020 - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the terms "solicit" and "solicitation" mean the entry onto real property used for residential purposes by a person for the purpose of communicating with an occupant of the property, whether the communication is verbal, visual or in writing. 
(Ord. 89-5 § 2, 1989) 
5.32.030 - Registration statement required-Contents. 
    All persons desiring to solicit at five or more dwelling units in the city during any eight-hour period shall file with the city recorder a registration statement, on forms provided by the city recorder, containing the following information: 
A.  The name of the person registering and desiring to solicit; 
B.  Whether the person registering is a natural person, partnership, corporation or association, and 
1.  If a natural person, the business or residence address and telephone number of the person, 
2.  If a partnership, the names of all partners and the principal business address and telephone number of each partner, 
3.  If a corporation, the person registering must state whether it is organized under the laws of Oregon or is a foreign corporation, and must show the mailing address, business location, telephone number, name of the individual in charge of the Portland-area office of such corporation and the registered agent of the corporation, and the names of all officers and directors or trustees of said corporation, and, if a foreign corporation, the place of incorporation, 
4.  If an association, the registration statement shall show the association's principal business address and telephone number, if any, and shall show names and principal business or residence addresses and telephone numbers of all members of the association, unless they exceed ten (10) in number, in which case the application shall so state and the person registering may alternatively list the names and principal business or residence addresses and telephone numbers of the officers and directors or trustees of the association. If the association is part of a multistate organization or association, the mailing address and business location of its central office shall be given, in addition to the mailing address and business location of its Portland-area office; 
C.  A brief description of the nature of the organization if the person registering is a partnership, association or corporation, and an explanation from all persons of the intended purpose of the solicitation; 
D.  The names, mailing address and telephone number of all individuals who will be in direct charge or control of the solicitation and the number of persons who will be actually involved in the solicitation activity. One of the named individuals shall be designated to receive any notice or communication from the city or the public concerning the solicitation activities; 
E.  The time period within which the solicitation is to be made, giving the date of the beginning of solicitation and its projected conclusion; 
F.  A description of the methods and means by which the solicitation is to be accomplished and the approximate locations and dates on which those locations will be visited; 
G.  The names of any other cities in which the person registering has solicited within the past five years, but in the event that the person registering has solicited in more than five other cities, the person registering may list the five cities located closest to Sheridan; 
H.  A statement that if a certificate of registration is granted, such certificate will not be used as or represented to be an endorsement by the city or any of its officers or employees; 
I.  The names of any officer, director, trustee, partners, corporation, or any current agent or employee engaging in the solicitation who has signed a consent decree or order in the last five years or who has been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude within the past five years, and the nature of the offense, or consent decree or order, the state where the conviction or consent decree or order occurred, and the year of such conviction, or consent decree, or order; 
J.  An explanation of the reasons, if the person registering is unable to provide any of the foregoing information, why such information is not available; 
K.  The registration statement must be signed by the applicant, if the person registering is an individual; if the person registering is a partnership, by a partner; if a person registering is a corporation or an association, by an officer. The individual signing the registration statement shall sign the statement and swear or affirm before an Oregon notary that he or she has carefully read the registration statement and that all the information contained therein is true and correct. 
(Ord. 89-5 § 5 (part), 1989) 
5.32.040 - Public inspection of registration information. 
    The registration statement and information submitted with the registration statement are public records available for public inspection during normal city business hours. 
(Ord. 89-5 § 5 (part), 1989) 
5.32.050 - Registration fee. 
A.  Except as provided in subsection B of this section, every registration statement shall be accompanied by a registration fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) to compensate the city for the cost of administering this registration program, and such fee will not be refunded if a certificate or registration is not issued. 
B.  The city recorder may waive the registration fee if a person is indigent and the purpose of the solicitation is either: (1) in connection with the assemblaging of people, instruction or their political representatives or application to the legislature as protected by Article I, Section 26 of the Oregon Constitution; or (2) in connection with their freedom of religion as protected by Article I, Section 3 of the Oregon Constitution. 
(Ord. 89-5 § 6, 1989) 
5.32.060 - Issuance of certificate of registration-Revocation. 
A.  After a review of the registration statement to determine its compliance with Section 5.32.030, and, within ten (10) working days of the receipt of the registration statement, the city recorder shall either issue a certificate of registration, in the form provided by Section 5.32.070, or notify the person registering that the registration statement does not comply with the requirements of Section 5.32.030, and specifically point out what information or explanation has not been furnished that is required before a certificate of registration can be issued. If the person registering is engaged in an activity for which a business license is required by this chapter, proof of a valid business license shall be furnished prior to the issuance of the certificate. 
B.  A certificate of registration shall be revoked by the city recorder if a registered person, or one or more solicitors engaged on behalf of that person, are convicted or plead guilty or no contest to a cumulative minimum of three violations of Section 5.32.080(A) occurring within any thirty (30) calendar-day period in connection with or on behalf of the solicitation of the registered person. A certified copy of the municipal court record of plea or conviction is conclusive proof that a violation has occurred. The period of revocation shall be for sixty (60) calendar days, during which the person may not receive a certificate of registration. Within five working days of receipt of notification that a registered person has been convicted, plead guilty or no contest to the third violation, the city recorder shall notify the person designated in the registration statement to receive notice of the action to revoke, in writing, five days prior to the effective date of the revocation. The person may appeal the recorder's decision to the city council by filing a notice of appeal with the city recorder within ten (10) days of the effective date of the revocation. During the pendency of the appeal, the order to revoke is stayed. 
(Ord. 89-5 § 7, 1989) 
5.32.070 - Form of certificate of registration-Term. 
A.  The city recorder shall prescribe the form of the certificate of registration. Each such certificate shall have the following printed prominently thereon: "THE ISSUANCE OF THIS CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION IS NOT AN ENDORSEMENT BY THE CITY OF SHERIDAN OR ANY OF ITS OFFICERS OR EMPLOYEES." Each certificate of registration shall bear a registration number which is the same as the file containing the registration statement filed by the registrant. 
B.  Every certificate of registration issued by the city recorder shall contain a termination date upon which the certificate shall expire, which date shall be the termination of the solicitation period specified in the registration statement or one year from the date of issuance, whichever is less. 
C.  The certificate of registration shall contain a list of the acts prohibited by Section 5.32.080. 
(Ord. 89-5 § 8, 1989) 
5.32.080 - Prohibited acts-Penalties. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to: 
1.  Solicit before nine a.m. or after nine p.m. when the local time is daylight savings time or after eight p.m. when the local time is standard time, without the consent of the occupant to do so; 
2.  Solicit without first having obtained a registration certificate pursuant to Section 5.32.060, if required by that section; 
3.  Violate the terms of a registration certificate issued pursuant to Section 5.32.060; 
4.  Solicit after a registration certificate has been revoked, pursuant to Section 5.32.060; 
5.  Allow, suffer or permit any person soliciting on their behalf or under their direction to commit any act prohibited by this section; 
6.  Provide false or fraudulent information on a registration statement; 
7.  Leave written materials upon real property where a sign conforming to the requirements of Section 5.32.090 is posted; 
8.  Solicit upon real property where a sign conforming to the requirements of Section 5.32.090 is posted; 
9.  Allow, suffer or permit any person to solicit on their behalf after a registration certificate has been revoked, pursuant to Section 5.32.060. 
B.  Violation of subsection (A)(1) through (7) of this section is punishable as a civil infraction. 
C.  Violation of subsection (A)(8) of this section is punishable as a Class C misdemeanor under state law. 
D.  Violation of subsection (A)(9) of this section is a Class C misdemeanor under state law. See Section 5.32.110. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(l) and (m) (part), 2000; Ord. 89-5 § 3, 1989) 
5.32.090 - "No solicitation" sign. 
A.  If an occupant of real property chooses to not invite solicitors onto their property, the occupant may post a "NO SOLICITATION" sign pursuant to this section. The effect of the posting of such a sign is to express the refusal of the occupant to grant consent to any person to enter their real property to solicit, except to those persons exempt from these provisions by Sections 5.32.030 and 5.32.120(D). 
B.  Signs posted pursuant to this section shall be posted on or near the boundaries of the property at the normal point of entry, and 
1.  Signs must be no smaller than six inches in height by eight inches in width; and 
2.  Signs must contain the words "NO SOLICITATION" and the reference to Section 5.32.080 of this chapter in characters no less than one-half inch in height. 
C.  For real property possessing no apparent barriers to entry at the boundaries of the property which limit access to the primary entrance of a structure located on the property, placement of the sign at the primary entrance to the structure constitutes compliance with this section. 
(Ord. 89-5 § 9, 1989) 
5.32.100 - Evidence of violations. 
A.  It shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of Section 5.32.080(A)(7) if written material is found on real property upon which a sign conforming to the requirements of Section 5.32.090 has been posted. The person responsible for such written material shall be the person identified in the written material as its proponent, sponsor, distributor or potential beneficiary of the communication conveyed. 
B.  For the purposes of Section 5.32.080(A)(5) and (9), if a person solicits on behalf of a person registered pursuant to Section 5.32.030, it is presumed that the person registered allowed, suffered or permitted solicitation. 
(Ord. 89-5 § 10, 1989) 
5.32.110 - Violation after registration is revoked. 
A.  No person shall allow, suffer or permit any person to solicit on their behalf after a registration certificate has been revoked, pursuant to Section 5.32.060. 
B.  For purposes of subsection A of this section, the term "solicit" is defined in Section 5.32.020. 
C.  A violation of this section is a Class C misdemeanor under state law. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(m) (part), 2000; Ord. 89-5 § 11, 1989) 
5.32.120 - Defense to violations-Exemptions. 
A.  It is an affirmative defense to an alleged violation of Section 5.32.080(A)(1), (7) or (8) that the person charged with the violation or crime had received actual or constructive consent of the occupant prior to entering the real property. Constructive consent to enter real property may be implied from the circumstances of each instance, the relationship of the parties and actual or implied contractual relationships. 
B.  The occupant of real property shall be considered to have given constructive consent to enter real property for the purpose of solicitation between the hours of nine a.m. and nine p.m. when the local time is daylight savings time, or before eight p.m. when the local time is standard time, if they have not posted a "No Solicitation" sign pursuant to Section 5.32.090. 
C.  Nothing in this section shall be construed to authorize the entry into a structure located on real property. The right to enter any structure must be otherwise provided for by law. 
D.  Officers, employees or agents of a governmental entity while performing activities within the scope of their office, employment or agency, are exempt from the requirements of this chapter. 
E.  No person may be charged with a violation of any subsection of Section 5.32.080 or Section 5.32.110 in connection with an act committed between four p.m. and nine p.m. on each October 31st. 
(Ord. 89-5 § 4, 1989) 
Chapter 5.36 - TAXICABS 

5.36.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Motor vehicle" means and includes every self-propelled vehicle by or upon which any person or persons may be transported or carried upon any public highway, street or alley. 
    "Person" means and includes natural persons of either sex, firms, copartnerships, associations and corporations, whether acting by themselves, agents or employees. 
    "Taxicab" means and includes every motor vehicle, except cars for rent without drivers, used for the transportation of passengers for hire and not operated exclusively over a fixed and defined route. 
(Ord. 75-1 §§ 1-3, 1975) 
5.36.020 - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of operating any of the vehicles defined in Section 5.36.010 without first securing a license therefor under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 75-1 § 4, 1975) 
5.36.030 - Application. 
    Every person desiring to obtain a license for the operation of a taxicab under this chapter shall file written application therefor with the city recorder of the city, setting forth the name of the person to whom the license is to be issued and the number of vehicles proposed to be operated, the name of the motor vehicle, the seating capacity of each and the number of the state license of each such vehicle; and should the state license number of such vehicle be changed during the life of such license, such change shall be forthwith reported to the city recorder. 
(Ord. 75-1 § 6, 1975) 
5.36.040 - License fees. 
    There shall be paid to the city recorder by each taxi service operating in the city an annual license fee of twelve dollars ($12.00) for each year or part of year that such service operates within the said city, and a further annual license fee of twelve dollars ($12.00) for each taxicab operated, all to be paid in advance. 
(Ord. 75-1 § 7, 1975) 
5.36.050 - Insurance required. 
    No taxicab permit shall be issued or continued in operation unless there is filed with the city recorder and approved by the city attorney satisfactory evidence of a liability insurance policy or policies of an insurance company or companies showing that there is in full force and effect a liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state of Oregon. The policy of insurance shall contain a provision against cancellation except upon thirty (30) days' prior written notice to the city council. This insurance shall apply to each vehicle operated under the taxicab permit in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for bodily injury to any one person; and the amount of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for the injuries to more than one person which are sustained in the same accident; and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage resulting from any one accident; and agreeing to pay to any judgment creditor to the extent of the amount specified in such policy any final judgment rendered against the injured for liability imposed by law for damages on account of bodily injuries or death, or from damages resulting from the owner's maintenance or use of any taxicab owned or operated under the taxicab permit. 
(Ord. 75-1 § 5, 1975) 
5.36.060 - Transfer of permit prohibited without consent. 
    No taxicab permit shall be sold, assigned, mortgaged, hypothecated or otherwise transferred without the consent of the common council of the city. 
(Ord. 75-1 § 9, 1975) 
5.36.070 - Revocation. 
    A taxicab permit issued under this chapter may be revoked or suspended by the common council of the city if the holder thereof has violated any of the provisions of this chapter or discontinued operations for more than fifteen (15) continuous days, or has violated any of the ordinances of the city, or laws of the United States or the state of Oregon, the violations of which reflect unfavorably on the fitness of the holder to offer public transportation. Prior to suspension or revocation, the holder shall be given notice of the proposed action to be taken and shall have an opportunity to be heard. 
(Ord. 75-1 § 10, 1975) 
5.36.080 - Inspection of vehicles. 
    All vehicles operating under authority of this chapter shall be inspected from time to time by the chief of police for the purpose of determining if the same are clean, properly equipped, of good appearance, and in safe condition for the transportation of passengers. At the time of such inspection, the chief of police shall determine for the guidance of the public the classification and the capacity of the vehicle inspected. No person shall drive or operate, or engage in the business of operating any taxicab, unless and until it has been inspected and approved by the chief of police. 
(Ord. 75-1 § 11, 1975) 
5.36.090 - Display of rate card required. 
    Each taxicab operated under this chapter shall have a rate card setting forth the authorized rates of fare displayed in such a place as to be in view of all passengers. 
(Ord. 75-1 § 12, 1975) 
5.36.100 - Use of taxi services. 
A.  No person shall refuse to pay the legal fee of any of the vehicles mentioned in this chapter after having hired the vehicle. 
B.  No person shall hire any taxicab with intent to defraud the person from whom it was hired of the value of such service. 
(Ord. 75-1 § 13, 1975) 
5.36.110 - Most direct route required. 
    Each driver of a taxicab employed to carry passengers to a definite point shall take the most direct route possible which will carry the passenger safely and expeditiously to his or her destination. 
(Ord. 75-1 § 14, 1975) 
5.36.120 - Report of property left in vehicles. 
    The driver of any taxicab shall promptly notify the chief of police or the city recorder of the city within twenty-four (24) hours of all property of value left in his or her vehicle by any passenger. 
(Ord. 75-1 § 15, 1975) 
5.36.130 - Passenger limits. 
    No driver of any taxicab shall carry more than two persons in excess of the ordinary seating capacity for which said taxicab or vehicle was designed and built. No more than two persons shall be permitted in the seat with the driver or chauffeur, and no person or passenger shall be allowed to be or remain on the doors, steps or running board of any taxicab while the same is in motion. 
(Ord. 75-1 § 16, 1975) 
5.36.140 - Operation of taxicabs. 
    No driver of any taxicab shall drive or operate the same while intoxicated or operate the same in a careless or reckless manner, or use any profane, obscene language, or smoke without the consent of the passengers. 
(Ord. 75-1 § 17, 1975) 
5.36.150 - Driver's permit and license required. 
    No person shall operate a taxicab for hire upon the streets of the city, and no person who owns or controls a taxicab shall permit it to be so driven, and no taxicab authorized by the city shall be driven at any time for hire, unless the taxicab driver has first obtained and has then in force a taxicab driver's permit issued under the provisions of this chapter by the chief of police of the city and also a driver's license from the state of Oregon which is then in force. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(n) (part), 2000; Ord. 75-1 § 18, 1975) 
5.36.160 - Driver's permit-Validity and denial. 
    No person may drive or operate any taxicab without first obtaining a driver's permit from the chief of police. Each permit shall be valid for the remainder of the calendar year issued, expiring on December 31st of said period. A taxicab driver's permit shall not be issued to: 
A.  A person who has been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude or narcotics; 
B.  A person who has been convicted of a "major traffic offense" as defined in ORS 153.500(5) within two years immediately preceding application for a permit; 
C.  A person not possessing a valid driver's license issued by the state of Oregon. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(n) (part) and 1(o), 2000; Ord. 75-1 § 19, 1975) 
5.36.170 - Driver's permit application requirements. 
    The chief of police shall require the applicant for a driver's permit to be fingerprinted and photographed and to submit the names of three references. When possible, such references shall be residents of the city. A fee of five dollars ($5.00) shall be charged each applicant for a taxicab driver's permit, whether or not said permit is issued. 
(Ord. 75-1 § 20, 1975) 
5.36.180 - Posting of permit required. 
    Every taxicab driver shall post his or her taxicab driver's permit in such place as to be in full view of all passengers while the driver is operating the taxicab. 
(Ord. 75-1 § 21, 1975) 
5.36.190 - Suspension or revocation of driver's permit. 
    Every taxicab driver granted a permit under this chapter shall comply with all city ordinances and with all state and federal laws. Failure to do so shall constitute a ground for the suspension or revocation of the taxicab driver's permit by the common council of the city. However, a taxicab driver's permit may not be revoked unless the driver has received notice and has had an opportunity to present evidence in his or her behalf. 
(Ord. 75-1 § 22, 1975) 
5.36.200 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.  A person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall: 
1.  Upon the first conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00); 
2.  Upon the second conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00); 
3.  Upon the third or further conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. 
B.  Each day's violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense, punishable as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. 88-3 (part), 1988; Ord. 75-1 § 24, 1975) 
Chapter 5.40 - SALE OF SECONDHAND, USED OR SURPLUS PERSONAL PROPERTY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2009-07, §§ 1-9, adopted July 20, 2009, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion herein as Ch. 5.40 was at the discretion of the editor. See also the Code Comparative Table and Disposition List. 

5.40.010 - Purpose. 
    The city council finds that perpetual, prolonged and extended yard sales in residential areas, if continued indefinitely, tend to become retail businesses in residential areas and zones, create noise, traffic congestion, unsightly signage, and other nuisance and often violate the zoning regulations of the city. The rules and regulation are designed to control and restrict yard sales in order to protect the public health, safety and convenience of the citizens of Sheridan and to restrict sales to casual or occasional occurrences only, in keeping with the character of the residential neighborhoods. The city council finds a need to limit, regulate, restrict and control yard sales. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 7-20-2009) 
5.40.020 - Definitions 
    Yard sale shall mean and include all general sales, open to the public, conducted from or on a residential premise in all zoning districts, or on vacant lots or other unused real property, for the purpose of disposing of personal property including, but not limited to all sales entitled "garage", "lawn", "yard", "attic", "porch", "room", "backyard", "patio", "moving", "flea market", "estate", or "rummage" sale. This definition shall not include a situation where no more than five specific items are offered for sale, all advertisement of such sale specifically names these items to be sold and the items are not publicly displayed for sale. 
    Personal property shall mean property which is owned, utilized and maintained by an individual or members of a residence or acquired in the normal course of living in or maintaining a residence, such as, but not limited to, household items, clothing, tools, toys, recreation equipment or other used or secondhand items normally found in and about the home and advertised to the public. It does not include merchandise which was purchased for resale or obtained on consignment. 
    Person shall mean any natural person or persons, association, partnership, firm corporation or other entity. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 2, 7-20-2009) 
5.40.030 - Authorization. 
    Yard sales are permitted within the municipal limits of the City of Sheridan under certain terms and conditions as herein set forth. It shall be unlawful for any individual to sell or offer for sale, under authority granted by this chapter, property other than personal property. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 3, 7-20-2009) 
5.40.040 - Permit. 
(a)  A permit shall be required for any person conducting a yard sale within the municipal limits of the City of Sheridan. The permit must be procured prior to the commencement of the sale and may be obtained during normal business hours in the office of the city recorder.
