3.  Upon the third or further conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. 
B.  Each day's violation of any provision of this title shall constitute a separate offense, punishable as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. 88-3 (part), 1988; Ord. 66-10 § 38, 1966) 
9.04.030 - Working prisoners. 
    In any conviction for violation of this title or any other ordinance of the city where the penalty fixed by the court is confinement in the city jail for any term, the court additionally may order that such convicted person, during the term of imprisonment, labor upon the streets or public works of the city under the direction of the proper authorities. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 39, 1966) 
Chapter 9.08 - OFFENSES BY OR AGAINST PUBLIC OFFICERS AND GOVERNMENT 

9.08.010 - Taking, retention, or mutilation of public records. 
A.  No person, without proper authority, shall take or remove any public record, document, book, paper or personal property of any kind owned by the city. 
B.  No person, without proper authority, shall mutilate or destroy any public record, document, book or paper on file or kept on record in any public office of the city. 
C.  No person shall retain any public record, document, book or paper after lawful demand has been made for the return thereof. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 34, 1966) 
9.08.020 - Escape of prisoners from custody. 
A.  No person shall aid or attempt to aid in the escape of a confined prisoner, make available, or provide anything calculated to aid in such escape. 
B.  No person shall knowingly aid an escaped prisoner by offering shelter, clothing, food, or any other thing or service which would aid or abet the escape of such prisoner. 
C.  No person in the custody of an officer of the city and no prisoner confined in the city jail or in any other place where prisoners are kept or confined shall escape or attempt to escape from such custody or confinement. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 8, 1966) 
9.08.030 - Interference with police. 
A.  No person shall hinder, delay, obstruct, resist, or refuse to assist any police officer or person duly empowered with police authority who is acting in the discharge of his or her duty. 
B.  No person shall help anyone escape or attempt to escape from the custody of a police officer or other person duly empowered with police authority. 
C.  No person shall deliver, by any method whatsoever, any intoxicating liquor or narcotic drug to any person confined in the city jail, or attempt to convey or deliver to any such person any article without the permission and consent of the officer in charge. 
D.  No person shall impersonate, falsely assume, or pretend to be a law enforcement officer. 
E.  No person shall use or permit the use of property for planning or promoting criminal activities or for violation of city ordinances. 
F.  No person shall operate any generator or electromagnetic wave or cause a disturbance of such magnitude as to interfere with the proper functioning of any police radio communication system of the city. 
G.  No person shall knowingly make or file with the police department of the city any false, misleading, or unfounded statement or report concerning the commission or alleged commission of any offense or crime. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 9, 1966) 
9.08.040 - Interference with fire control equipment and personnel. 
A.  No person shall intentionally give any false alarm of fire or aid or abet in the commission of such an act. 
B.  No person shall lead, ride or drive any horse or other animal or operate any vehicle over or upon any fire hose, or disturb or injure in any manner any hose, engine, appliance or apparatus belonging to or used by the fire department. 
C.  No person at a fire shall conduct himself or herself in a disorderly manner or refuse to obey promptly any order of any member of the fire department or resist, obstruct or hinder any member of the fire department. 
D.  No person, unless authorized by the fire chief, shall unfasten, open, draw water from, or otherwise interfere with any fire hydrant. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 10, 1966) 
Chapter 9.12 - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE AND DECENCY 

9.12.010 - Assault and battery. 
    No person shall, with or without a weapon, attack, assault, or commit a battery upon any other person. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 2, 1966) 
9.12.020 - Consumption of intoxicating liquor. 
    No person shall drink any intoxicating liquor in any public place or in a motor vehicle in a public place. This section shall not apply to the drinking of any intoxicating liquor in any establishment wherein the same may be sold for premises consumption under the laws of the state of Oregon. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(e) (part), 2000; Ord. 66-10 § 3, 1966) 
9.12.030 - Disorderly conduct. 
    ORS 166.025 pertaining to disorderly conduct is adopted, together with all terms and conditions contained therein, by the city, and is incorporated into this section. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(r), 2000: Ord. 66-10 § 4, 1966) 
9.12.040 - Harassment. 
    A person commits the offense of harassment if, with intent to harass, annoy or alarm another person, he or she: 
A.  Subjects another to offensive physical contact; or 
B.  Publicly insults another by abusive or obscene words or gestures in a manner likely to provoke a violent response. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(u), 2000; Ord. 76-7, 1976: Ord. 66-10 § 37A, 1966) 
9.12.050 - Loitering or peeping. 
A.  No person shall loiter, prowl, or wander upon the property or premises of another, without the consent of, or without lawful business with, the owner or occupant thereof. 
B.  No person, while being upon the property or premises of another, shall look or peep in the door or window of any building or structure situated thereon which is inhabited or used as a dwelling, without the consent of, or without lawful business with, the owner or occupant thereof. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(s), 2000; Ord. 66-10 § 20, 1966) 
9.12.060 - Expectoration. 
    No person shall expectorate upon any sidewalk or street, or on or in any public building, except in receptacles provided for that purpose. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 35, 1966) 
9.12.070 - Disorderly houses. 
    "Disorderly house" means any house or place kept or maintained for the purpose of prostitution, fornication, lewdness, gambling, or other immoral purposes, including any place, room or building used for the consumption, sale or disposition of liquor or narcotic drugs contrary to law. 
A.  No person shall establish, maintain or aid in the establishment or maintenance of a disorderly house as that term is defined in this section. 
B.  No person shall knowingly visit or frequent any disorderly house, provided that this section shall not apply to physicians and officers acting in the discharge of their professional duties. 
C.  No person shall knowingly lease any building under his or her control for the purpose of permitting the establishment of a disorderly house. Any person whose property has been leased and is used as a disorderly house shall, upon learning of its use, immediately take appropriate action to oust the occupants thereof. 
D.  No person shall solicit or entice another person to visit or enter a disorderly house. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 18, 1966) 
9.12.080 - Prostitution. 
    ORS 167.007 and 167.002 pertaining to prostitution are adopted, together with all terms and conditions contained therein, by the city, and are incorporated into this section. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(t), 2000: Ord. 66-10 § 21, 1966) 
Chapter 9.16 - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 

9.16.010 - Injury to or removal of property. 
A.  No person, without proper authority, shall cut, remove, deface, or in any manner injure or damage real or personal property of the city within or without the corporate limits. 
B.  No person, without proper authority, shall cut, destroy, remove or injure any plant, flower, shrub, tree or bush growing upon any property owned or controlled by the city within or without the corporate limits. 
C.  No person shall wilfully deface, injure, tamper with, break or destroy any property, real or personal, belonging to or under the control of another. 
D.  No person shall ride or permit a horse on public property except upon a road or other area where a motor vehicle may be lawfully operated. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 32, 1966) 
9.16.020 - Destruction of official notices and signs. 
    No person, without proper authority, shall wilfully deface, alter, remove, or tear down any official notice or bulletin, or any official sign, signal or barricade posted or placed in conformity with the law. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 31, 1966) 
9.16.030 - Trespass. 
    ORS 164.205 and 164.245 pertaining to trespass are adopted, together with all terms and conditions contained therein, by the city, and are incorporated into this section. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(w), 2000: Ord. 66-10 § 29, 1966) 
9.16.040 - Burglar's tools. 
    ORS 164.235 pertaining to burglar's tools is adopted, together with all terms and conditions contained therein, by the city, and is incorporated into this section. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(v), 2000: Ord. 66-10 § 15, 1966) 
9.16.050 - Obstructing passageways. 
A.  No person shall, except as otherwise permitted by ordinance, obstruct, cause to be obstructed, or assist in obstructing pedestrian or vehicular traffic on any sidewalk or street. 
B.  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the delivery of merchandise or equipment, provided that no person shall permit such merchandise or equipment to remain on any street or sidewalk beyond a reasonable time. 
C.  No person shall permit any merchandise, equipment or other obstruction to remain on any street or sidewalk. 
D.  No person shall use any street or sidewalk, or any portion thereof, for selling, storing or displaying merchandise or equipment except as may otherwise be provided by ordinance. 
E.  No unauthorized person shall deposit any earth, gravel or debris upon any street or sidewalk. 
F.  Notwithstanding subsections C or D of this section, community organizations and businesses may display and sell their wares during special organizational events and community events upon issuance of a special permit by the city recorder for such purpose. Application for such permits shall be made to the city recorder and shall be accompanied by an application and permit fee of two dollars ($2.00). Upon issuance of the permit by the city recorder, the chief of police shall inspect the display and sales materials to ensure that said materials do not present an obstruction to passage or other danger to the public safety. The chief of police shall be empowered to request the alteration of locations of displays which either obstruct the passageway or present other dangers to the public safety, and may, where such request does not abate such hazard, cancel any such permit issued by the city recorder and issue a citation or citations for violations of applicable statutes, ordinances or regulations. 
G.  Under circumstances found to be appropriate by the city council, the city council may, by resolution duly adopted, and subject to any conditions and restrictions contained in such resolution, waive, alter, or otherwise modify any of the conditions or restrictions set forth in this section. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(x), 2000; Ord. 94-3 § 1, 1994; Ord. 83-7, 1983; Ord. 66-10 § 13, 1966) 
9.16.060 - Obstructing sidewalks. 
A.  No person or group of persons shall gather or stand upon a sidewalk or public pathway in such a manner as to prevent, impede or obstruct the free passage of pedestrian traffic. 
B.  No person or group of persons shall fail or refuse to move on or disperse when lawfully ordered to do so by a police officer. 
C.  No person shall permit a cellar door or grate located in or upon a sidewalk to remain open except when such entrance is being used, and, when being used, such entrance shall have adequate safeguards to protect pedestrians using the sidewalk. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 33, 1966) 
Chapter 9.20 - THEFT AND RELATED OFFENSES 

9.20.010 - Buying, receiving or concealing stolen property. 
    No person shall buy, receive, conceal, or attempt to buy property that is known or should be known to such person to have been stolen. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 16, 1966) 
9.20.020 - Theft in the second degree. 
    ORS 164.405 pertaining to theft in the second degree is adopted, together with all terms and conditions contained therein, by the city, and is incorporated into this section. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(y), 2000: Ord. 66-10 § 30, 1966) 
9.20.030 - Property dealings with persons intoxicated or under the influence of narcotics. 
    No pawnbroker, junk dealer, chattel loan broker, or other person shall purchase property from, advance or loan money to, or have dealings respecting the title to property with a person who is in an intoxicated condition or under the influence of a narcotic drug. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 17, 1966) 
9.20.040 - Defrauding of innkeepers. 
A.  No person shall, with intent to defraud, obtain any food, lodging, or other accommodations at any hotel, apartment house, boarding house, tourist camp, trailer camp, or restaurant. 
B.  No person shall, after having obtained food, lodging, or other accommodation at any hotel, apartment house, boarding house, tourist camp, trailer camp, or restaurant, surreptitiously remove his or her baggage and clothing from such hotel, apartment house, boarding house, tourist camp, trailer camp, or restaurant without first paying or tendering payment for such food, lodging, or other accommodation. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 22, 1966) 
Chapter 9.24 - LIQUOR REGULATIONS 

9.24.010 - Definition. 
    As used in this chapter, the term "alcoholic liquor" means any alcoholic beverage containing more than one-half of one percent alcohol by volume, and every liquid or solid, patented or not, containing alcohol and capable of being consumed by a human being. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 28 (part), 1966) 
9.24.020 - Adoption of state regulations. 
    The provisions of the Oregon Liquor Control Act and all regulations adopted by the Oregon Liquor Control Commission relating to alcoholic liquor are adopted as part of this chapter, excepting only as otherwise lawfully provided by this chapter and other ordinances of the city. It is unlawful for any person within the limits of the city to fail to comply with any provisions of the Oregon Liquor Control Act or the regulations of the Oregon Liquor Control Commission. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 28 (part), 1966) 
9.24.030 - License required-Sale of alcoholic liquor generally. 
A.  No person shall sell, solicit, peddle, or take orders for alcoholic liquor unless such person has a license from the Oregon Liquor Control Commission. No person shall sell or offer for sale, in any manner or to any person, alcoholic liquor other than as his or her license permits. 
B.  Each licensee of the Oregon Liquor Control Commission shall be responsible for his or her licensed premises and liable to prosecution for any violation of any provision of this chapter pertaining to his or her licensed premises and for any act or omission of any servant, agent or employee of such licensee in violation of any provision of this chapter. 
C.  No person or licensee of the Oregon Liquor Control Commission holding a license from such commission permitting only the sale and consumption of malt beverages shall knowingly permit any alcoholic liquor containing more than four percent of alcohol by weight to be brought upon or be consumed upon the premises. 
D.  No person shall sell for consumption on the premises any alcoholic liquor during the time the polls are open on any day on which an election is held throughout the state. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 28 (part), 1966) 
9.24.040 - Prohibitions generally. 
A.  No person shall drink or consume any alcoholic liquor in or upon any public street, public place, alley, park, school grounds, or other public grounds unless such public place is so licensed. 
B.  No person shall keep, sell, give away, or otherwise dispose of or consume any alcoholic liquor in any public dance hall or in any room or building used for public dancing except for establishments licensed by the OLCC where dancing is allowed. 
C.  No person under an order of interdiction shall possess, purchase, or offer or attempt to purchase any alcoholic liquor. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(z), 2000; Ord. 66-10 § 28 (part), 1966) 
9.24.050 - Purchase or possession by or sale to minors. 
A.  No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years shall attempt to purchase, purchase, or acquire alcoholic liquor. No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years may have in his or her possession or be under the influence of alcoholic liquor except in a private residence, accompanied by his or her parent or guardian, and with such parent's or guardian's consent. 
B.  No person shall sell alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years. No person, other than his or her parent or guardian, shall give any alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
C.  No person who is the owner, lessee, tenant, occupant, possessor, or the agent or employee thereof, of property or premises in such person's possession or control, shall allow, permit or suffer any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to consume any alcoholic liquor upon such premises or property, to be upon such premises or property while under the influence of intoxicating liquor, or to be upon said property or premises while in the possession of alcoholic liquor, unless the person under twenty-one (21) years of age is accompanied by, and in the presence of, his or her parent or guardian. 
D.  No minor, either for himself or herself or as agent or employee of another, shall sell, offer for sale, or deliver any alcoholic liquor, nor may any person employ, hire, or engage any minor to sell, offer for sale, or deliver any such liquor. 
E.  No person, including a minor, shall, for the purpose of securing any right, benefit or privilege denied minors by this chapter, represent falsely that he or she is of any age other than his or her true age, or represent falsely a minor to be twenty-one (21) years of age or older. 
F.  Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as prohibiting a parent or guardian of a minor from giving such minor alcoholic liquor and permitting him or her to consume the same within the home of such parent or guardian, or at such other private place not in view of the public where the parent or guardian is present. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 28 (part), 1966) 
9.24.060 - Violations. 
    Whenever any officer arrests any person for violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, the officer shall take into his or her possession all alcoholic liquor and other property which the person so arrested has in his or her possession or on his or her property or premises, which is apparently being used in violation of this chapter. If the person so arrested is convicted and it is found that the liquor and other property has been used in violation of this chapter, the same shall be forfeited to the city or the Oregon Liquor Control Commission. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 28 (part), 1966) 
Chapter 9.28 - MARIJUANA 

9.28.010 - Offenses. 
A.  A person commits the offense of illegal possession of marijuana if he or she knowingly and unlawfully possesses less than one avoirdupois ounce of marijuana. 
B.  A person commits the offense of illegal use of marijuana if he or she knowingly and unlawfully uses or is under the influence of marijuana. 
C.  A person commits the offense of illegal promotion of marijuana if he or she knowingly maintains, frequents or remains at a place where less than one avoirdupois ounce of marijuana is found at the time an arrest is made under this chapter. 
(Ord. 75-5 §§ 1-3, 1976) 
9.28.020 - Violation-Penalty. 
    ORS 475.992(4)(f) pertaining to marijuana is adopted, together with all terms and conditions contained therein, by the city, and is incorporated into this section. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(aa), 2000: Ord. 88-3 (part), 1988; Ord. 75-5 § 4, 1976) 
9.28.030 - Moratorium on marijuana dispensaries. 
A.  There is hereby established a moratorium on the operation of any registered medical marijuana facility in any area subject to the jurisdiction of the City of Sheridan, Oregon, for a period of time ending at 5:00 p.m. on May 1, 2015. 
B.  As used in this section, "registered medical marijuana facility" includes any facility that dispenses marijuana pursuant ORS 475.314, or any other provision of Oregon law. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 2, 4-7-2014) 
Chapter 9.30 - REGULATION OF TOBACCO AND ELECTRONIC SMOKING DEVICES 

9.30.010 - Definitions. 
    "Inhalant delivery system." 
A.  A device that can be used to deliver nicotine or cannabinoids in the form of a vapor or aerosol to a person inhaling from the device; or 
B.  A component of a device described in this subsection or a substance in any form sold for the purpose of being vaporized or aerosolized by a device described in this subsection, whether the component or substance is sold separately or is not sold separately. Inhalant delivery system does not include: 
1.  Any product that has been approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration for sale as a tobacco cessation product or for any other therapeutic purpose, if the product is marketed and sold solely for the approved purpose. 
    "Smoking." Any inhaling, exhaling, burning, or carrying any lighted or heated tobacco product or substance in any manner or in any form. Smoking also includes the use of an inhalant delivery system which creates a vapor, in any manner or in any form. 
    "Tobacco products." Bidis, cigars, cheroots, stogies, periques, granulated, plug cut, crimp cut, ready rubbed and other smoking tobacco, snuff, snuff flour, cavendish, plug and twist tobacco, fine-cut and other chewing tobaccos, shorts, refuse scraps, clippings, cuttings and sweepings of tobacco and other forms of tobacco, prepared in a manner that makes the tobacco suitable for chewing or smoking in a pipe or otherwise, or for both chewing and smoking; or cigarettes as defined in ORS 323.010 (1). "Tobacco product" also includes any electronic smoking device. "Tobacco product" does not mean any product that the United States Food and Drug Administration has approved as a tobacco use cessation product. 
(Ord. No. 2015-07, § 1, 11-6-2015) 
9.30.020 - Smoking prohibited in public places. 
A.  Smoking shall be prohibited on all publically owned property located within the city, including, but not limited to the following places: 
1.  Every room, chamber, place of meeting or public assembly, including school buildings under the control of any board, council commission, committee, including joint committees, or agencies of the city or any political subdivision of the city, including during such time as a public meeting is in progress, to the extent such a place is subject to the jurisdiction of the city or where smoking has been prohibited by the owner of such public property; 
2.  On the street and on all sidewalks along both sides of South Bridge Street from the north point of the intersection of S W Harrison Street on the west side of the street to the terminus of the South Bridge sidewalks at Main Street, and from the southeast corner of SE Madison Street on the east side of the street to the terminus of the South Bridge sidewalks at Main Street. 
3.  On the sidewalks along the south side of East Main Street and on East Main Street from the north end of the bridge to the point that aligns with the east boundary of NE Faulconer Street. 
4.  On the sidewalks along the north side of East Main Street from the northeast corner of North Bridge Street and East Main Street east to the northeast corner of the intersection of NE Faulconer Street and East Main Street. 
5.  On the sidewalks along the south side of West Main from the southeast corner of North Bridge Street and East Main Street west to a point along the extended straight line from the northwest corner of NW Washington Street. 
6.  On the sidewalks along the north side of West Main Street from the northeast corner of North Bridge Street and East Main Street west to the northwest corner of NW Washington Street. 
7.  Within any city park unless permitted by authorized signage. 
(Ord. No. 2015-07, § 1, 11-6-2015) 
9.30.030 - Smoking prohibited outside certain private property. 
    A person may not smoke or carry a lighted or heated tobacco product within ten (10) feet of the following parts of public places or places of employment as such terms are defined by state law for the purposes of ORS 433.854: 
A.  Entrances; 
B.  Exits; 
C.  Windows that open; and 
D.  Ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area. 
(Ord. No. 2015-07, § 1, 11-6-2015) 
9.30.040 - Places where smoking is not regulated. 
    This chapter does not regulate the area within the right of way of public streets which are not identified in Section 9.30.020, or where the smoking is undertaken within or on an automobile, vehicle, bicycle, skateboard or other means of conveyance while such automobile, vehicle, bicycle, skateboard or other means of conveyance is moving along and between the curbs of the right of way. 
(Ord. No. 2015-07, § 1, 11-6-2015) 
9.30.050 - Tobacco sales to minors prohibited. 
A.  No person, other than a minor's custodial parent or guardian, shall sell or otherwise provide tobacco products to a minor under the age of eighteen (18) years old." 
(Ord. No. 2015-07, § 1, 11-6-2015) 
Chapter 9.32 - OFFENSES BY OR AGAINST MINORS 

9.32.010 - Curfew. 
A.  No minor person under the age of eighteen (18) years shall idle, wander, stroll, or play in or upon the public streets, sidewalks, parks, playgrounds, or other unsupervised places after the hour of ten p.m. and before the hour of four a.m.; provided, however, that this subsection shall not apply to a minor person accompanied by, or with the written permission of, an adult person having the care and custody of the minor person, engaged in legitimate business, school work, religious activities, emergencies, or errands of mercy, or where the employment of such person makes it necessary to be in such place. 
B.  (1)  No person between the ages of seven and eighteen (18) years and who has not completed the twelfth grade shall be in or upon any street, highway, park, alley or other public place as defined in ORS 161.015(10)(1997) during regular school hours except while attending school unless: 
a.  The minor is accompanied by a parent, guardian, or other person eighteen (18) years of age or over and authorized by the parent or by law to have care and custody of the minor; 
b.  The minor is then engaged in a lawful pursuit or activity which requires the presence of the minor in such public places during regular school hours and is authorized by the minor's parent, guardian, or other person having the legal care and custody of the minor; 
c.  The minor is lawfully emancipated pursuant to ORS 419B.550 to 419B.558; or 
d.  The minor is authorized and approved to be away from school as provided in ORS 339.030 and 339.065, but is not suspended or expelled. 
e.  These exemptions extend to those who are home schooled as that term is defined by Oregon Revised Statutes. 
(2)  For purposes of this section, regular school hours are those hours for the full time school which the child would attend in the school district in which the child resides, on any day for which school is in session, unless such day is scheduled vacation or holiday observed by the school. 
a.  A child being home schooled shall comply with the regular hours and schedule established by the home school. 
(3)  A police officer or any other law enforcement officer is hereby authorized and empowered to take charge of any person under the age of eighteen (18) years violating the provisions of this ordinance and take the minor into protective custody pursuant to and subject to the requirements of ORS 419B.150. 
C.  No parent, lawful guardian or other person lawfully charged with the care and custody of a minor person under the age of eighteen (18) years shall permit such minor person to violate the provisions of subsection A or B of this section. A violation of this subsection C may be treated as a violation of Sheridan Municipal Code Section 9.32.060. 
(Ord. No. 2008-08, § 1, 12-15-2008; Ord. 67-12, 1967; Ord. 66-10 § 27, 1966) 
9.32.020 - Prohibited conduct by minors. 
A.  No minor shall enter, visit, or loiter in or about a poolroom, billiard room, cardroom, tavern or bar. No person operating or assisting in the operation of such a place may permit a minor to loiter therein or permit such minor to engage in any game of cards, billiards, pool, dice, pinball, darts, games of like character, or games of chance either for amusement or otherwise. 
B.  No person under the age of eighteen (18) years shall smoke, use or possess a cigar, cigarette, tobacco or an inhalant delivery system in any form in any public place. For the purposes of this sub-section the term "inhalant delivery system" shall be defined as set forth in ORS 431.840. 
C.  No person shall falsely represent his or her age in order to obtain cigars, cigarettes or tobacco or in order to engage in games or loiter in places proscribed by subsection A of this section. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 36 (part), 1966) 
(2015-06, § 1, 8-20-2015) 
9.32.030 - Prohibited conduct against minors. 
A.  No person shall employ a minor in or about a beer parlor, liquor establishment, cardroom, poolroom, shooting gallery, or dance hall. 
B.  No person shall sell, barter, trade, give, or in any manner furnish to a person under the age of eighteen (18) years for his or her consumption, cigars, cigarettes, or tobacco in any form, any compound in which tobacco forms a component part, or an inhalant delivery system. For the purposes of this sub-section the term "inhalant delivery system" shall be defined as set forth in ORS 431.840. 
C.  No person shall purchase property or an article of value from a person under eighteen (18) or have dealings respecting the title of property in the possession of a person under eighteen (18) without the written consent of the parent or guardian of such person under eighteen (18). 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(cc), 2000; Ord. 66-10 § 36 (part), 1966) 
(Ord. No. 2015-06, § 2, 8-20-2015) 
9.32.040 - Endangering the welfare of a minor. 
    ORS 163.575 pertaining to endangering the welfare of a minor is adopted, together with all terms and conditions contained therein, by the city, and is incorporated into this section. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(bb), 2000: Ord. 66-10 § 36 (part), 1966) 
9.32.050 - Children confined in vehicles. 
A.  No person who has under his or her control or guidance a child under seven years of age shall at any time lock, confine, permit to be locked or confined or leave such child unattended in an automobile, stage, coach, bus or other vehicle on the streets, alleys or public ways for a period of time longer than thirty (30) consecutive minutes. 
B.  It is lawful and the duty of a police officer or other peace officer, finding a child or children confined in violation of the terms of this section, to enter such automobile, stage, coach, bus or other vehicle and remove such child; such officer having the right, if reasonably necessary, to use such force as may be necessary to effect an entrance to the vehicle or place where such child may be confined in order to remove the child. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 37, 1966) 
9.32.060 - Failure to supervise a child. 
A.  A person commits the offense of failing to supervise a child if the person is the parent, lawful guardian or other person lawfully charged with the care or custody of a child under eighteen (18) years of age and the child: 
1.  Commits an act that brings the child within the jurisdiction of the juvenile court under ORS 419C.005; 
2.  Violates the curfew ordinance of the city; 
3.  Fails to attend school as required under ORS 339.010; or 
4.  Allows the child to keep stolen property or controlled substances, as defined by state of Oregon law, which are obtained without a legal prescription. 
B.  Nothing in this section applies to a child-caring agency as defined in ORS 418.205 or to foster parents. 
C.  In a prosecution of a person for failing to supervise a child under subsection (A)(1) of this section, it is an affirmative defense that the person: 
1.  Is the victim of the act that brings the child within the jurisdiction of the juvenile court; or 
2.  Reported the act to the appropriate authorities. 
D.  In a prosecution of a person for failing to supervise a child under subsection A of this section, it is an affirmative defense that the person took reasonable steps to control the conduct of the child at the time the person is alleged to have failed to supervise the child. 
E.  In a prosecution of a person for failing to supervise a child under subsection (A)(1) of this section, the municipal court may order the person to pay restitution under ORS 137.103 to 137.109 to a victim for pecuniary damages arising from the act of the child that brings the child within the jurisdiction of the juvenile court. The amount of restitution ordered under this subsection may not exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
F.  If a person pleads guilty or is found guilty of failing to supervise a child under this section and if the person has not previously been convicted of failing to supervise a child, the court: 
1.  May warn the person of the penalty for future convictions of failing to supervise a child and may suspend imposition of sentence; 
2.  May not order the person to pay restitution under this section. 
G.  If a person pleads guilty or is found guilty of failing to supervise a child under this section and if the person has only one prior conviction for failing to supervise a child, the court, with the consent of the person, may suspend imposition of sentence and order the person to complete a parent effectiveness program approved by the court. Upon the person's completion of the parent effectiveness program to the satisfaction of the court, the court may discharge the person. If the person fails to complete the parent effectiveness program to the satisfaction of the court, the court may impose a sentence authorized by this section. There may be only one suspension of sentence under this subsection with respect to a person. 
H.  Failing to supervise a child is an offense punishable by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. 95-6 § 1, 1995) 
Chapter 9.36 - WEAPONS 

9.36.010 - Discharge of weapons. 
A.  No person other than an authorized peace officer shall fire or discharge a gun or other weapon, including spring or air-actuated pellet guns, air guns, or BB guns, or a weapon which propels a projectile by use of gunpowder or other explosive, jet, or rocket propulsion. 
B.  The provisions of this section shall not be construed to prohibit the firing or discharging of a weapon by any person in the defense or protection of his or her property, person or family. 
(Ord. 66-10 § 7, 1966) 
9.36.020 - Concealed weapons. 
    No person other than an authorized peace officer or person licensed pursuant to ORS 166.291, as now or hereafter amended, shall carry concealed on or about his or her person in any manner any revolver, pistol, other firearm, any knife having a blade that projects or swings into position by force of a spring or by centrifugal force and commonly known as a switchblade knife, dirk, dagger, stiletto, metal knuckles, or weapon the use of which could inflict injury upon a person or property. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(dd) and (ee), 2000; Ord. 66-10 § 6, 1966) 
Chapter 9.40 - MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES 

9.40.010 - Misrepresentation in lodging accommodation register. 
    No person shall write, cause to be written, or knowingly permit to be written, in any register in any hotel, lodging house, rooming house, or other place where transients are accommodated in the city, any other or different name or designation than the true name or designation of the person so registered, or the name or designation by which such person is generally known. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(e) (part), 2000; Ord. 66-10 § 23, 1966) 
Title 10 - VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC 
Chapters: 
Chapter 10.04 - STATE TRAFFIC LAWS ADOPTED 
Sections: 

10.04.010 - Statutory traffic offenses. 
    Oregon Revised Statutes Chapters 801 through 822 (the Oregon Vehicle Code), Chapter 153 and Chapter 823 are incorporated by reference within the city of Sheridan traffic code as though they were set forth fully therein. 
(Ord. 97-5 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 96-14 § 1, 1996) 
10.04.020 - Violation. 
    Any violation defined by the statute chapters listed in Section 10.04.010 shall be an identical violation of the Sheridan traffic code. 
(Ord. 97-5 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 96-14 § 2, 1996) 
Chapter 10.08 - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
Sections: 

10.08.010 - Powers of the council. 
A.  Subject to state laws, the city council shall exercise all municipal traffic authority for the city except those powers specifically and expressly delegated herein or by another ordinance. 
B.  The powers of the council shall include but not be limited to: 
1.  Designation of through streets; 
2.  Designation of one-way streets; 
3.  Designation of truck routes; 
4.  Designation of parking meter zones; 
5.  Restriction of the use of certain streets by any class or kind of vehicle to protect the streets from damage; 
6.  Authorization of greater maximum weights or lengths for vehicles using city streets than specified by state law; 
7.  Initiation of proceedings to change speed zones; 
8.  Revision of speed limits in parks. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 4, 1971) 
10.08.020 - Duties of the city administrator. 
A.  The city administrator or his or her designate shall exercise the following duties: 
1.  Implement the ordinances, resolutions and motions of the council and his or her own orders by installing traffic control devices. Such installations shall be based on the standards contained in the Oregon manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways; 
2.  Establish, maintain, remove or alter the following classes of traffic controls: 
a.  Crosswalks, safety zones, and traffic lanes, 
b.  Intersection channelization and areas where drivers of vehicles shall not make right-, left- or U-turns, and the time when the prohibition applies, 
c.  Parking areas and time limitations, including the form of permissible parking (e.g., parallel); 
3.  Issue oversize or overweight vehicle permits. 
B.  Public Danger. Under conditions constituting a danger to the public, the city administrator or his or her designate may install temporary traffic control devices deemed by him or her to be necessary. 
(Ord. 71-6 §§ 5 and 6, 1971) 
10.08.030 - Basis for standards. 
    The regulations of the city administrator or his or her designate shall be based upon: 
A.  Traffic engineering principles and traffic investigations; 
B.  Standards, limitations and rules promulgated by the State Highway Commission; 
C.  Other recognized traffic control standards. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 7, 1971) 
10.08.040 - Authority of police and fire officers. 
A.  It shall be the duty of police officers to enforce the provisions of this title. 
B.  In the event of a fire or other public emergency, officers of the police and fire department may direct traffic as conditions require, notwithstanding the provisions of this title. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 8, 1971) 
10.08.050 - Traffic control devices. 
A.  Obedience to and Alteration of Control Devices. 
1.  No person shall disobey the instruction of a traffic officer or a traffic control device. 
2.  No unauthorized person shall install, move, remove, obstruct, alter the position of, deface, or tamper with a traffic control device. 
B.  Evidence. The existence of a traffic control device shall be prima facie evidence that the device was lawfully authorized and installed. 
C.  Existing Control Devices. Traffic control devices installed prior to the adoption of the ordinance codified in this chapter are lawfully authorized. 
(Ord. 71-6 §§ 9-11, 1971) 
10.08.060 - Impoundment of vehicles. 
A.  Whenever a vehicle is placed in a manner or location that constitutes an obstruction to traffic or a hazard to public safety, a police officer shall order the owner or operator of the vehicle to remove it. If the vehicle is unattended, the officer may cause the vehicle to be towed and stored at the owner's expense. The owner shall be liable for the costs of towing and storing, notwithstanding that the vehicle was parked by another or that the vehicle was initially parked in a safe manner but subsequently became an obstruction or hazard. 
B.  The disposition of a vehicle towed and stored under authority of this section shall be in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 10.24 of this code relating to impoundment and disposition of vehicles abandoned on the city streets. 
C.  The impoundment of a vehicle will not preclude the issuance of a citation for violation of a provision of this title. 
D.  Stolen vehicles may be towed from public or private property and stored at the expense of the vehicle owner. 
E.  Whenever a police officer observes a vehicle parked in violation of a provision of this title, if the vehicle has four or more unpaid parking violations outstanding against it, the officer may, in addition to issuing a citation, cause the vehicle to be impounded. A vehicle so impounded shall not be released until all outstanding fines and charges have been paid. Vehicles impounded under authority of this subsection shall be disposed of in the same manner as provided in subsection B of this section. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 44, 1971) 
10.08.070 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  ORS 153.615 and 153.620 pertaining to penalties for traffic infractions are adopted, together with all terms and conditions contained therein, by the city, and are incorporated into this section. 
B.  Each day's violation of any provision of this title shall constitute a separate offense, punishable as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. 03-11 § 1, 2003; Ord. 00-1 § 1(ff), 2000; Ord. 93-2, 1993; Ord. 88-3 (part), 1988; Ord. 71-6 § 45, 1971) 
Chapter 10.12 - SUPPLEMENTAL TRAFFIC CONTROL REGULATIONS 
Sections: 

10.12.010 - Rules of road. 
    In addition to state law, the following shall apply to the operation of vehicles upon the streets of the city: 
A.  The operator of a vehicle shall not back the vehicle unless the movement can be made with reasonable safety and without interfering with other traffic, and shall yield the right-of-way to moving traffic and pedestrians. 
B.  The operator of a vehicle in the traffic lane shall have the right-of-way over an operator of a vehicle departing from a parking space. 
C.  No operator of a vehicle shall pull away from a curb or other parking area without giving an appropriate turn signal when other traffic may be affected. 
D.  Where a stop sign is erected at or near the entrance to an intersection, the operator of a vehicle approaching shall bring the vehicle to a stop before crossing a stop line or crosswalk; or, if none, then before entering the intersection. Stopping at a point which does not yield an unobstructed view of traffic on the intersecting street shall not constitute compliance with the requirements of this section. 
E.  Notwithstanding an indication by a traffic control device to proceed: 
1.  No operator of a vehicle shall enter an intersection unless there is sufficient space on the opposite side of the intersection to accommodate his or her vehicle without obstructing the passage of other vehicles. 
2.  No operator of a vehicle shall enter a marked crosswalk, whether or not at an intersection, unless there is sufficient space on the opposite side of the crosswalk to accommodate his or her vehicle without obstructing the passage of pedestrians. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 12, 1971) 
10.12.020 - Crossing private property. 
    No operator of a vehicle shall proceed from one street to an intersecting street by crossing private property. This provision shall not apply to the operator of a vehicle who stops on the property for the purpose of procuring or providing goods or services. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 13, 1971) 
10.12.030 - Emerging from vehicle. 
    No person shall open the door of a motor vehicle into a traffic lane without first ascertaining that it can be done in safety. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 14, 1971) 
10.12.040 - Unlawful riding. 
A.  No operator shall permit a passenger and no passenger shall ride on a vehicle upon a street except on a portion of the vehicle designed or intended for the use of passengers. This provision shall not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty, or to a person riding within a truck body in space intended for merchandise. 
B.  No person shall board or alight from a vehicle while the vehicle is in motion upon a street. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 15, 1971) 
10.12.050 - Clinging to vehicles. 
    No person riding upon a bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, rollerskates, sled, or other device shall attach the device or himself or herself to a moving vehicle upon a street, nor shall the operator of a vehicle upon a street knowingly allow a person riding on any of the above vehicles or devices to attach himself or herself, the vehicle, or the device to his or her vehicle. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 16, 1971) 
10.12.060 - Sleds on streets. 
    No person shall use the streets for traveling on skis, toboggans, sleds, or similar devices, except where authorized. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 17, 1971) 
10.12.070 - Damaging sidewalks and curbs. 
A.  The operator of a vehicle shall not drive upon a sidewalk or roadside planting strip except to cross at a permanent or temporary driveway. 
B.  No unauthorized person shall place dirt, wood, or other material in the gutter or space next to the curb of a street with the intention of using it as a driveway. 
C.  No person shall remove a portion of a curb or move a motor vehicle or device moved by a motor vehicle upon a curb or sidewalk without first obtaining authorization and posting bond, if required. A person who causes damage shall be held responsible for the cost of repair. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 18, 1971) 
10.12.080 - Obstructing streets. 
A.  No unauthorized person shall obstruct the free movement of vehicles or pedestrians using the streets. 
B.  No person shall park or stand a vehicle in such a manner or location that it constitutes a hazard to public safety or an obstruction on the street. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 19, 1971) 
10.12.090 - Removing glass and debris. 
    A party to a vehicle accident or a person causing broken glass or other debris to be upon a street shall remove the glass and other debris from the street. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 20, 1971) 
Chapter 10.16 - PEDESTRIANS 
Sections: 

10.16.010 - Use of sidewalks. 
    A pedestrian shall not use a roadway for travel when a sidewalk is available. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 30, 1971) 
10.16.020 - Pedestrians must use crosswalks. 
    No pedestrian shall cross a street other than within a crosswalk in blocks with marked crosswalks, or if within one hundred fifty (150) feet of a marked crosswalk. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 31, 1971) 
10.16.030 - Crossing street at right angles. 
    A pedestrian shall cross a street at a right angle, unless crossing within a crosswalk. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 32, 1971) 
10.16.040 - Obedience to traffic lights and bridge and railroad signals. 
    At an intersection where a pedestrian control light is in operation, no pedestrian shall start to cross the street except when the walk signal is illuminated. Where only vehicle control lights are in operation, no pedestrian shall start to cross the street except when the green light is illuminated. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 33, 1971) 
Chapter 10.20 - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 
Sections: 

10.20.010 - Method of parking. 
A.  No person shall stand or park a vehicle in a street other than parallel with the edge of the roadway, headed in the direction of lawful traffic movement, and with the curbside wheels of the vehicle within twelve (12) inches of the edge of the curb, except where the street is marked or signed for angle parking. 
B.  Where parking space markings are placed on a street, no person shall stand or park a vehicle other than in the indicated direction and, unless the size or shape of the vehicle makes compliance impossible, within a single-marked space. 
C.  The operator who first begins maneuvering his or her motor vehicle into a vacant parking space on a street shall have priority to park in that space, and no other vehicle operator shall attempt to deprive him or her of his or her priority or block his or her access. 
D.  Whenever the operator of a vehicle discovers that his or her vehicle is parked close to a building to which the fire department has been summoned, the operator shall immediately remove the vehicle from the area, unless otherwise directed by police or fire officers. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 22, 1971) 
10.20.020 - Prohibited parking and standing. 
    In addition to the state motor vehicle laws prohibiting parking, no person shall park or stand: 
A.  A vehicle upon a bridge, viaduct, or other elevated structure used as a street or within a street tunnel, unless authorized; 
B.  A vehicle in an alley other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of persons or materials, but in no case for a period in excess of thirty (30) consecutive minutes; 
C.  A motor truck, motor bus, or semi-trailer weighing (with or without load) or recreational vehicle in excess of twelve thousand (12,000) pounds shall be prohibited from parking on any city street. Except while actually engaged in the process of loading or unloading passengers and cargo, and then only for a period of time not in excess of thirty (30) minutes, or the actual time necessary to complete said loading or unloading activity; 
D.  A vehicle upon a parkway or freeway, except as authorized; 
E.  Any vehicle requiring registration with the state of Oregon that is currently unregistered or whose registration has expired for a period of six months or more. 
F.  Within a yellow zone. 
(Ord. 03-12 § 1, 2003; Ord. 03-10 § 1, 2003; Editorially amended during 2000 codification; Ord. 94-5 § 5, 1994; Ord. 92-10, 1993; Ord. 71-6 § 23, 1971) 
10.20.030 - Prohibited parking. 
    No operator shall park and no owner shall allow a vehicle to be parked upon a street for the principal purpose of: 
A.  Displaying the vehicle for sale; 
B.  Repairing or servicing the vehicle, except repairs necessitated by an emergency; 
C.  Displaying advertising from the vehicle; 
D.  Selling merchandise from the vehicle, except when authorized; 
E.  Storage, or as junkage or dead storage for more than twenty-four (24) hours unless a temporary emergency permit has been issued by the city clerk. The city clerk may issue a one-time temporary permit for a maximum seven-day period for hardship reasons. A copy of the permit will be given to the police department and the person issued the permit will conspicuously post such permit on the windshield or driver's window of the vehicle to which such temporary emergency permit shall pertain. (Editorially amended during 2000 codification; Ord. 94-5 § 6, 1994; Ord. 78-8 § 1, 1978: Ord. 71-6 § 24, 1971) 
10.20.040 - Use of loading zone. 
    No person shall stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time, other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of persons or materials, in a place designated as a loading zone when the hours applicable to that loading zone are in effect. In no case, when the hours applicable to the loading zone are in effect, shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed the time limits posted. If no time limits are posted, then the use of the zone shall not exceed thirty (30) minutes. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 25, 1971) 
10.20.050 - Action by police officer. 
    Whenever a police officer shall find a motor vehicle parked unattended with the ignition key in the vehicle, the police officer is authorized to remove the key from the vehicle and deliver the key to the person in charge of the police station. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 26, 1971) 
10.20.060 - Lights on parked vehicle. 
    No lights need be displayed upon a vehicle that is parked in accordance with this title upon a street where there is sufficient light to reveal a person or object at a distance of at least five hundred (500) feet from the vehicle. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 27, 1971) 
10.20.070 - Moving a vehicle. 
    The moving of any vehicle within the block shall not be deemed to extend the time limits of parking. 
(Ord. 78-8 § 2, 1978; Ord. 71-6 § 28, 1971) 
10.20.080 - Exemption. 
    The provisions of this title regulating the parking or standing of vehicles shall not apply to a vehicle of the city, county, or state or public utility while necessarily in use for construction or repair work on a street; or a vehicle owned by the United States while in use for the collection, transportation or delivery of mail. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 29, 1971) 
10.20.090 - Citation on illegally parked vehicle. 
    Whenever a vehicle without an operator is found parked in violation of a restriction imposed by this title, the officer finding the vehicle shall take its license number and any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its owner, and shall conspicuously affix to the vehicle a traffic citation for the operator to answer to the charge against him or her or pay the penalty imposed within five days during the hours and at a place specified in the citation. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 40, 1971) 
10.20.100 - Failure to comply with traffic citation attached to parked vehicle. 
    If the operator does not respond to a traffic citation affixed to such vehicle within a period of five days, the city may send to the owner of the vehicle to which the traffic citation was affixed a letter informing him or her of the violation and warning him or her that, in the event the letter is disregarded for a period of five days, a warrant for his or her arrest will be issued. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 41, 1971) 
10.20.110 - Owner responsibility. 
    The owner of a vehicle placed in violation of a parking restriction shall be responsible for the offense, except where the use for the vehicle was secured by the operator without the owner's consent. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 42, 1971) 
10.20.120 - Registered owner presumption. 
    In a prosecution of a vehicle owner charging a violation of a restriction on parking, proof that the vehicle at the time of the violation was registered to the defendant shall constitute a presumption that he or she was then the owner in fact. 
(Ord. 71-6 § 43, 1971) 
Chapter 10.24 - ABANDONED VEHICLES ON STREETS AND ALLEYS 
Sections: 

10.24.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise: 
    "Abandoned" means left in a state of disuse, unclaimed, or in a damaged, inoperable or dismantled condition upon the streets or alleys of the city. 
    "City" means the city of Sheridan. 
    "Costs" means the expense of removing, storing or selling an impounded vehicle. 
    "Chief of police" means and includes any authorized law enforcement officer of the city. 
    "Owner" means any individual, firm, corporation or unincorporated association with a claim, either individually or jointly, of ownership or any interest, legal or equitable, in a vehicle. 
    "Vehicle" means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway, except devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Ord. 94-5 § 1, 1994; Ord. 1250 § 1, 1957) 
10.24.020 - Determination of vehicle owner-Hearing. 
A.  It shall be the duty of the police department whenever a vehicle is found abandoned upon the streets or alleys in the same position for a period of forty-eight (48) hours to: 
1.  Make a diligent inquiry as to the name and address of the owner of the vehicle; 
2.  Examine such vehicles for license number, vehicle identification number, make, style and other information which will aid in the identification of the ownership of the vehicle; 
3.  Make inquiry to the Oregon State Motor Vehicles Division for the name and address of the registered owner and lien holder; 
4.  Contact the owner or one with right of possession and request removal of the vehicle; 
5.  If the owner is not found, to place a notice upon the windshield, or some other prominent part of the vehicle easily seen by the passing public. Such notice shall state: 
a.  The name of the officer and the pertinent law being violated, 
b.  That the police will take the vehicle into custody if it is not moved within seventy-two (72) hours, 
c.  That towing and storage charges will be levied as a lien on the vehicle, 
d.  And that the owner, or that person with a right of possession, may request a pre-tow hearing by submitting a written request to the chief of police before the seventy-two (72) hours have elapsed. 
B.  A pre-tow hearing shall be held: 
1.  At the request of the owner or one with a right of possession of the vehicle; 
2.  Before a hearings officer appointed by the mayor and council; 
3.  Within forty-eight (48) hours of when such written request is received; 
4.  At which the validity of the finding of a violation shall be the only issue for determination. 
(Ord. 94-5 § 2, 1994; Ord. 81-4 (part), 1981; Ord. 79-1 (part), 1979; Ord. 1250 § 2, 1957) 
10.24.030 - Impoundment. 
    If no hearing is requested, or the validity of the finding of a violation is sustained by the hearings officer, and the vehicle is not removed within seventy-two (72) hours of the posting of the notice, the police shall impound the vehicle and remove it for storage. 
(Ord. 81-4 (part), 1981; Ord. 79-1 (part), 1979; Ord. 1250 § 3, 1957) 
10.24.040 - Notice to owner. 
    If the owner has been identified, he or she shall be notified immediately by registered mail that such vehicle is held by the police department of the city. The notice shall also state: 
A.  The reason for the impoundment; 
B.  The existing costs incurred to date; 
C.  An estimate of various future costs; 
D.  That a hearing may be requested to contest the validity of the impoundment (if no pre-tow hearing was held), and the validity of any charges assessed by the police department in connection with the impoundment; 
E.  The right to redeem the vehicle immediately by payment of the charges levied; 
F.  That unless the owner redeems the vehicle(s) within fifteen (15) days of the mailing of a notice and pays all costs and charges, the vehicle(s) will be advertised for sale. If the vehicle is appraised at a value of more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), the vehicle will be disposed of pursuant to the procedures set forth in Oregon Revised Statutes Chapter 819.220 as amended. If the vehicle is appraised at five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less, the vehicle will be disposed of to a certified wrecker. 
(Ord. 00-1 § 1(gg), 2000; Ord. 94-5 § 3, 1994; Ord. 81-4 (part), 1981; Ord. 1250 § 4, 1957) 
10.24.050 - Notice of sale. 
A.  If the owner cannot be identified after compliance with Section 10.24.020, or no claim is made by a notified owner within the time specified by Section 10.24.040(F), the chief of police shall cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the city a notice of sale. The notice of sale shall state: 
1.  The sale is of abandoned property in possession of the city; 
2.  A description of the vehicle, including the type, make, motor number, serial number, and any other information which will aid in accurately identifying the vehicle; 
3.  The terms of the sale; 
4.  The date, time and place of the sale. 
B.  The notice of sale shall be published two times; the first publication shall be made not less than ten (10) days prior to the date of the proposed sale, and the second shall be made not less than two days prior to the date of the proposed sale. 
(Ord. 1250 § 5, 1957) 
10.24.060 - Redemption by owner. 
A.  An owner may redeem a vehicle impounded under the provisions of this chapter, before a sale has taken place, by applying to the police department, whereupon he or she shall: 
1.  Submit evidence of his or her ownership or interest in the vehicle, satisfactory to the chief of police, that such claim is rightful; and 
2.  Pay the costs due and owing at the time the application to redeem is made. 
B.  Upon compliance with subsection A of this section, the chief of police shall execute a receipt for the owner and cause the vehicle to be returned to him or her. 
(Ord. 1250 § 6, 1957) 
10.24.070 - Sale to highest and best bidder-Proceeds of sale. 
A.  If no claim shall have been made to redeem an impounded vehicle before the time set for the sale of such vehicle, the chief of police shall hold a sale, at the time and place appointed, within the view of the vehicle to be sold. 
B.  The vehicle shall be sold to the highest and best bidder, providing that if no bids are entered, or those bids which are entered are less than the costs incurred by the city, the chief of police shall enter a bid on behalf of the city in an amount equal to such costs. 
C.  The proceeds of such sale shall be applied: 
1.  To the payment of costs incurred by the city; and 
2.  The balance, if any, shall be transferred to the treasurer of the city to be credited to the general fund. 
(Ord. 1250 § 7, 1957) 
10.24.080 - Certificate of sale. 
A.  At the time of payment of the purchase price, the chief of police shall execute a certificate of sale, in duplicate, the original of which shall be delivered to the purchaser, and the copy thereof filed with the city recorder of the city. 
B.  The certificate of sale shall be substantially as follows: 
CERTIFICATE OF SALE 
This is to certify that under the provisions of Ordinance No. ___ entitled "An Ordinance for the Impounding and Disposition of Abandoned Vehicles" and pursuant to due notice of the time and place of sale, I did on the ___ day of _____, 20___, sell at public auction to _______ for the sum of $_____ cash, he being the highest and best bidder, and that being the highest and best sum bid therefore, the following described personal property, to wit: 
(brief description of the property) 
And in consideration of the payment of the said sum of $_____, receipt whereof is hereby acknowledged, I have this day delivered to said purchaser the foregoing property. 
Dated this ___ day of _______, 20___. 
Note: The city of Sheridan assumes no responsibility as to the condition of title of the above described property. In case this sale shall for any reason be invalid, the liability of the city is limited to the return of the purchase price. 
C.  Upon such sale being consummated, the chief of police shall deliver the vehicle and the certificate of sale to the purchaser. Such sale and conveyance shall be without redemption. 
(Ord. 1250 §§ 8 and 9, 1957) 
10.24.090 - Applicability. 
    This chapter shall apply to all abandoned vehicles now in the possession of the city as well as to all such vehicles as may hereafter be impounded. 
(Ord. 1250 § 10, 1957) 
10.24.100 - Charges. 
    In the enforcement and execution of the provisions of this chapter, the chief of police shall charge and collect the following charges: 
A.  Reasonable towing charges; 
B.  Two dollars ($2.00) per day for storage. 
(Ord. 79-1 (part), 1979; Ord. 1250 § 11, 1957) 
Chapter 10.28 - IMPOUNDMENT OF UNINSURED VEHICLES 
Sections: 

10.28.010 - Impoundment of uninsured vehicle. 
    A police officer who reasonably believes that a person is driving an uninsured vehicle in violation of ORS 806.010, is driving without a valid driver's license in violation of ORS 807.010(1), or is driving while their driver's license is suspended in violation of ORS 811.175 and 811.182, as these are incorporated within the Sheridan traffic code, and who issues a citation into court to the driver for that offense, may, without prior notice, order the vehicle impounded until a person with right to possession of the vehicle complies with the conditions for release or the hearings officer orders that the vehicle be released. The police officer shall give notice that the vehicle has been impounded to the same parties, in the same manner and within the same time limits as provided in ORS 819.180, as it has been incorporated into the Sheridan traffic code, for notice after removal of a vehicle. 
(Ord. 97-5 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 96-14 § 3, 1996) 
10.28.020 - Hearing request. 
    A person entitled to lawful possession of a vehicle impounded pursuant to this chapter may request, in writing, within five business days of the impoundment, a hearing to contest the validity of the impoundment. The request shall be made to the city recorder. When a timely request for a hearing is made, a hearing shall be held before the municipal judge or such other hearings officer designated as such by the city council. 
(Ord. 97-5 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 96-14 § 4, 1996) 
10.28.030 - Conditions for release. 
    A vehicle impounded under this chapter shall be released to a person entitled to lawful possession upon proof of compliance with financial responsibility requirements for the vehicle, payment to the city of a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), and payment of any towing and storage charges. 
(Ord. 97-5 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 96-14 § 5, 1996) 
10.28.040 - Trial for uninsured vehicle. 
    The impounding police officer shall have the burden of proving by a preponderance of the evidence that there were reasonable grounds to believe that the vehicle was being operated in violation of ORS 806.010, as it is incorporated within the Sheridan traffic code. If the municipal judge or hearings officer finds that the impoundment of the vehicle was proper, the municipal judge or hearings officer shall enter an order supporting the removal and shall find that the owner or person entitled to possession of the vehicle is liable for usual and customary towing and storage costs. The municipal judge or hearings officer may also find the owner or person in possession of the vehicle liable for costs of the hearing. Such costs of the hearing shall become a lien upon the vehicle. 
(Ord. 97-5 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 96-14 § 6, 1996) 
Chapter 10.32 - BICYCLES, SKATEBOARDS, ROLLER SKATES AND CARTS 
Sections: 

10.32.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Bicycle" shall have the same meaning as that described in ORS 801.150. 
    "Cart" means any nonlicensed, nonvehicular device to which wheels are attached, whose purpose is the conveyance of persons or property, whether manually or mechanically operated. 
    "Roller skate" means any device with wheels which are attached to or a part of any shoe or boot. 
    "Skateboard" means any device with wheels attached to a surface; such surface being designed such that a person or persons may stand, sit or kneel upon it; and is propelled by foot or other mechanical means. 
(Ord. 87-4 § 1, 1987) 
10.32.020 - Operation prohibited in certain places at certain times. 
    It is unlawful to ride a bicycle upon, or operate a skateboard, roller skates or nonvehicular cart upon certain streets located within the city. Prohibited hours of operation of bicycles, skateboards, roller skates or carts and the location of streets or portions of sidewalks or streets to which such prohibition applies shall be designated by resolution of the council directing the police chief or his or her deputy to clearly mark the locations of the designated areas. 
(Ord. 87-4 § 2, 1987) 
10.32.030 - Exceptions. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall prevent any person from lawfully pushing a bicycle or cart or carrying roller skates or a skateboard upon the sidewalks or streets designated by the council pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. 87-4 § 3, 1987) 
10.32.040 - Careless or dangerous operation prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for a person to operate a bicycle, skateboard, roller skates or cart within the city in a careless or heedless manner which endangers the safety of the operator or the general public. 
(Ord. 87-4 § 4, 1987) 
10.32.050 - Impoundment-Bail. 
    All police officers of the city are authorized and directed to take up and impound for evidence any bicycles, skateboards, roller skates or carts which are found to be used in connection with violation of any provision of this chapter or ORS 814.400 through 814.480. Impounded property may be released by any officer to the parent or guardian of the offender, or to any adult offender upon the posting of a bail amount of not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. 87-4 § 5, 1987) 
10.32.060 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.  A person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall: 
1.  Upon the first conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00); 
2.  Upon the second conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00); 
3.  Upon the third or further conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. 
B.  Each day's violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense, punishable as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. 87-4 § 6, 1987) 
10.32.070 - Extension of impoundment. 
    In addition to imposing fines, the judge in his or her sound discretion, may extend the term of impoundment for any property used in the violation before the judge, said impoundment not to exceed sixty (60) days in duration. 
(Ord. 87-4 § 7, 1987) 
Chapter 10.36 - RECREATIONAL VEHICLES 
Sections: 

10.36.010 - Definition. 
    As used in this chapter, the term "recreational vehicle" means a vacation trailer or other unit with or without motive power which is designed for human occupancy and to be used temporarily for recreational or emergency purposes and has a gross floor space of less than four hundred (400) square feet. The term "recreational vehicle" also includes any self-propelled living quarters. 
(Ord. 92-9 § 1, 1992) 
10.36.020 - Permits required. 
A.  It is unlawful to occupy any recreational vehicle used for sleeping or living purposes within the city for a period of time exceeding fifteen (15) days, or to reside in any recreational vehicle in any public place in the city, without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city manager. 
B.  A recreational vehicle used for temporary sleeping purposes may be parked in the city outside of a trailer court and off of city streets or alleys, for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) days, if a permit is obtained from the city manager. The permit shall be temporary only, and no more than two permits shall be issued to a particular recreational vehicle in the same calendar year. 
C.  A permit may be issued by the city manager to park and utilize a recreational vehicle off city streets for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days for purposes of residing in a recreational vehicle on the same premises wherein a dwelling is being constructed and where the applicant has a current building permit for said construction. Prior to issuance of such ninety (90) day permit, the applicant shall furnish proof to the city manager that the recreational vehicle is fully self contained and presents no health hazard to the community with respect to water, sewer and garbage. Said permit shall be renewable for a period of thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. 92-9 § 2, 1992) 
10.36.030 - Fees. 
    The fees to be charged by the city for the aforementioned permits shall be established by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. 92-9 § 3, 1992) 
10.36.040 - Exceptions. 
    Recreational vehicles in approved recreational vehicle parks within the city are not affected by the provisions of this chapter. The parking of recreational vehicles in the city which are not used for sleeping or living quarters are not regulated by this chapter but are regulated by the general ordinances of the city regulating vehicular parking when parked on the city streets or alleys. 
(Ord. 92-9 § 4, 1992) 
10.36.050 - Wheel removal or placement on foundation not to affect applicability of provisions. 
    The removal of the wheels or the placement of a recreational vehicle on posts, footings or permanent or temporary foundation shall not be considered as removing said recreational vehicle from the regulations contained in this chapter. 
(Ord. 92-9 § 5, 1992) 
10.36.060 - Water and sanitary disposal. 
    It is unlawful for any person occupying or using any recreational vehicle within the city to connect said recreational vehicle to the septic or water facilities of the city water and sewer system except in accordance with the ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. 92-9 § 6, 1992) 
10.36.070 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.  A person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall: 
1.  Upon the first conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00); 
2.  Upon the second conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00); 
3.  Upon the third or further conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. 
B.  Each day's violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense, punishable as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. 92-9 § 7, 1992) 
Chapter 10.40 - RESIDENTIAL PARKING AND VEHICLE STORAGE REGULATIONS 
Sections: 

10.40.010 - Applicability. 
    Vehicle parking and storage on property zoned for residential purposes or properties containing residential development, shall be subject to the provisions in this chapter. 
(Ord. 02-7 § 1 (part), 2002) 
10.40.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall be defined as follows: 
    "Clear-vision area" means a triangular area on a lot at the intersection of two streets or a street and a railroad, two sides of which are lines measured from the corner intersection of the right-of-way lines for a distance of twenty (20) feet. The third side of the triangle is a line across the corner of the lot joining the ends of the other two sides. 
    "Multifamily developments" means a building containing three or more dwelling units designed for occupancy by three or more families living independently of each other. 
    "Parking" means the temporary storage of registered vehicles that are used on a daily or weekly basis. In this case, "registration" means a currently licensed and insured vehicle that may operate on the public streets and roads within the state. 
    "Storage" means to the long-term parking of vehicles, and may include, but is not limited to, automobiles, trucks, motorcycles, boats, trailers, recreational vehicles and similar equipment. Storage is distinguished from "parking" in that the vehicle is used occasionally or seasonally and often for recreational purposes. The term "storage" shall automatically apply to all non-registered vehicles and those registered vehicles that are not self-propelled. 
(Ord. 02-7 § 1 (part), 2002) 
10.40.030 - Parking. 
    Parking on property zoned for residential purposes or properties containing residential development, shall be limited to the driveway, garage and/or carport, or in the case of a multi-family development, on designated parking spaces within the development. 
A.  Yard Restrictions. Exclusive of driveways, it shall be prohibited for any automobile, truck, motorcycle, boat, trailer, recreational vehicle or similar vehicle to be parked or stored in a front yard or any yard adjacent to the street, for a period in excess of twenty-four (24) hours within a seven-day period. 
B.  Storage. No more than one additional space shall be provided for the storage of automobiles, trucks, motorcycles, utility trailers, house or vacation trailers, boats, recreational vehicles or other similar vehicles not located on a driveway or within a garage or carport. This space may be located adjacent to a driveway, or, in the rear or side yard; provided, the space shall not interfere with the clear-vision area. This storage space shall be improved with gravel, concrete, asphalt, or similar improvements such as brick or concrete paving stones. Dirt, bark dust, or similar material shall not be used as a surfacing material. No more than one vehicle shall be stored in this manner. 
C.  Multifamily Developments. There shall be no limit to the number of vehicle storage spaces provided for residents of a multi-family development, provided; the storage spaces do not reduce the number of parking spaces required by ordinance for the residents of the development, and, the storage spaces are improved in a manner similar to the parking spaces required for the residents. 
(Ord. 02-7 § 1 (part), 2002) 
Title 12 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES 
Chapter 12.04 - STANDARD SPECIFICATIONS FOR PUBLIC WORKS 

12.04.010 - Adoption of standards. 
A.  The city of Salem, Oregon, department of public works standard construction specifications and design standards, including all updates and modifications, are adopted as the city of Sheridan's department of public works standard construction specifications and design standards. 
B.  All planned unit developments, subdivisions and multifamily developments, as defined in the city of Sheridan development code, shall be required to maintain a current copy of the city of Salem, Oregon, department of public works standard construction specifications and design standards on-site during construction. 
(Ord. 95-13 §§ 1 and 2, 1995) 
Chapter 12.08 - STREET GRADES 

12.08.010 - Street grades designated on plats and maps. 
A.  The elevations and grades of those certain streets and portions thereof within the city set forth in the annexed plats and maps prepared by the city engineer shall be as designated on said plats and maps and as heretofore established by the said city engineer by virtue of the Works Progress Administration's works project No. 2709. 
B.  The grade of said streets and curbs shall be what is known as the straight grade. 
C.  The said maps and plats are on file in the office of the city recorder of the city of Sheridan and are marked Exhibit A for the purpose of identification and are incorporated in this chapter by reference thereto. 
(Ord. 1076 §§ 1-3, 1941) 
Chapter 12.12 - SIDEWALK AND DRIVEWAY CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS 

12.12.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall mean: 
    "Alley approach" means that portion of a sidewalk which crosses the entrance from any street to any dedicated alley. 
    "Driveway approach" means that portion of a service driveway lying within the sidewalk and constructed so as to allow the safe passage of vehicles across the sidewalk. 
    "Intersection" means the area of the public right-of-way which lies within the projection of two lot lines at the point where such lines meet at an angle to form a lot corner.
