    "Notice" means a written notice to the affected party directed to such party by first class or certified mail. Notice shall be deemed effective on the date such notice is deposited with a public or private mail carrier, postage pre-paid, and directed to such party at such party's last known address known to the city. 
    "Owner(s)" means that person or persons shown on the last tax assessment roll in the office of the county assessor of Yamhill County, Oregon. 
    "Remodeling" means a structural improvement or new construction made to any structure in which the new construction or improvement exceeds twenty-five (25) percent of the value of the improvements on the property as established by the Yamhill County tax assessor at the time a construction permit is obtained. 
    "Structure" means and includes all dwellings, commercial and industrial buildings, and other structure designed for human occupancy. 
(Ord. 92-2 § 1, 1992) 
12.12.020 - Applicability of requirements. 
    Except as may be limited by ORS 223.880, 366.460, 368.910, 373.020, 373.030, 447.310, or other applicable and paramount statutes, laws or regulations, the state of Oregon and the county of Yamhill shall be subject to the requirements of this chapter as it applies to state- or county-owned rights-of-way or abutting state- or county-owned property located within the city of Sheridan. 
(Ord. 92-2 § 2, 1992) 
12.12.030 - Duty to install sidewalk. 
A.  It is made the duty of every property owner whose property abuts upon any street that has been improved with hard-surface pavement, and the grade of which has been established by the installation of curbs at grade, to construct a concrete sidewalk conforming to the ordinances of the city prior to an occupancy permit being issued, or within one hundred eighty (180) days from the completion of any remodeling of any structure located upon the property of such owner. 
B.  It is made the duty of every property owner whose vacant, undeveloped or developed property abuts upon any street that has been improved with hard-surface pavement, and the grade of which has been established by the installation of curbs at grade, to construct a concrete sidewalk conforming to the ordinances of the city within three years from the date that the ordinance codified in this chapter 
(Ord. 92-2) took effect. (Ord. 95-10 § 1, 1995: Ord. 92-2 § 3, 1992) 
12.12.040 - Duty to maintain and keep in repair. 
A.  Real property owners in the city shall maintain and keep in repair all sidewalks in the public rights-of-way of the city that are in front of, adjacent to, or abutting upon any such owner(s) real property. Said repairs shall be completed within sixty (60) days after notice by the city manager. 
B.  An existing sidewalk shall be considered in a state of disrepair when the condition or defect is such as would create a danger to pedestrians. Such conditions shall include but not be limited to breakage, cracks, upheaval, irregular surfaces, vertical or horizontal dislocation at joints, degraded or deteriorated composition of concrete materials, accumulations of moss or other organic growths, and other visible hazards. 
(Ord. 92-2 § 4, 1992) 
12.12.050 - Installation and repairs to city specifications. 
    All installations and repairs undertaken pursuant to this chapter shall be according to city specifications as set forth in the provisions of this chapter, a copy of which shall at all times be available for public inspection in the office of the city recorder. 
(Ord. 92-2 § 5, 1992) 
12.12.060 - Injury or property damage. 
    The owner(s) of real property in the city shall be liable for any person suffering personal injury or property damage by reason of any defect in the sidewalk adjacent to or abutting upon the real property of the respective owner(s) thereof. 
(Ord. 92-2 § 6, 1992) 
12.12.070 - Obstructions. 
    It is made a duty of every property owner to remove any obstacle or obstruction to any sidewalk abutting or located on such property owner's property and to maintain and afford continuous unobstructed access to such sidewalk to the public. 
(Ord. 92-2 § 7, 1992) 
12.12.080 - Wheelchair ramps required at street intersections. 
    Whenever any sidewalk is repaired, replaced or newly constructed within the intersection of any public streets, such repair, replacement or new construction shall be completed to conform with the American Public Works Association standards for wheelchair ramps. Dimensions and specifications for wheelchair ramps shall be as set forth in the plans attached to the ordinance codified in this chapter as Exhibit A, which plans are made a part of this chapter. 
(Ord. 92-2 § 8, 1992) 
12.12.090 - Sidewalks at intersections-Sharing of costs. 
    Whenever any property owner constructs a sidewalk in compliance with this chapter in front of his or her premises along a city street, and part of such sidewalk is installed and constructed within the street intersection, or within the alley approach, the city shall pay and reimburse such property owner for that portion of such sidewalk being within the street intersection or alley approach at the prevailing rate per square foot and subject to the availability of city funds; provided that such property owner notifies the city of the completion of such sidewalk within sixty (60) days after the completion thereof, and such property owner had obtained the required permit for construction of said sidewalk and said sidewalk had been inspected and approved by the building official. In the event the property owner fails to comply with this section, the city shall not be obligated to reimburse said property owner for any of the cost of said sidewalk in said street intersection. 
(Ord. 92-2 § 9, 1992) 
12.12.100 - Construction permits and inspections required. 
A.  No person, firm, corporation or unit of government other than the city shall construct any sidewalk without first applying for and receiving a permit to so construct such sidewalk from the city manager. 
B.  No sidewalk shall be constructed by any person, firm, corporation or unit of government other than the city without the construction thereof being inspected by the city building official or his or her designee and approved by him or her as conforming to the standards of the city. 
(Ord. 92-2 § 10, 1992) 
12.12.110 - Sidewalk and driveway approach specifications. 
A.  All sidewalks and driveway approaches hereafter constructed within the city shall be constructed of concrete cement compounded of portland cement, clean sand, clean gravel and water in sufficient quantities to achieve a twenty-eight (28) day compressive strength of at least three thousand (3,000) pounds per square inch when tested in accordance with applicable standards of the American Society for Testing Materials. No white sand shall be used in such mix. Concrete shall be poured monolithically and shall be a minimum six-sack mix. 
B.  All sidewalks hereafter constructed or repaired shall be of the following minimum width, exclusive of any curb: 
1.  Within a commercial zone as defined by the zoning ordinance of this city, or adjacent to any property owned, used or to be used for school or public education purposes, the minimum width shall be eight feet, or shall conform to the existing width, if it is wider; 
2.  Elsewhere-five feet, except curb line walks shall be five feet inclusive of curb surface, or conform to existing width. 
C.  All sidewalks shall be four inches' minimum thickness and six inches' minimum thickness across driveways and alley approaches. 
D.  Sidewalks shall have a fall of .025 inches per foot from the property line toward the curb, and shall be so laid that the street side of the walk shall be at an elevation equal to that of the curb of the street, unless the city manager shall otherwise authorize. 
1.  Expansion joints one-half inch wide shall be placed at maximum intervals of thirty (30) feet and shall be placed wherever a new walk joins an existing walk, driveway or other solid object, and at points of direction change. 
2.  Sidewalks shall be divided into square blocks of no greater dimension than seven foot, by joints running across the walk at right angles to their length. Each joint shall be plainly marked with a deep cutter two inches in width. The edges of all blocks shall be smoothly marked with a three-inch edger and be free from broom marks. All sidewalks shall receive a broom finish. 
3.  Forms shall be free from warping or breaks and be of sufficient strength, and properly anchored and braced, to ensure holding of true lines and grades. 
E.  Where the earth is in an undisturbed condition, no sidewalk bed other than the earth needs to be used. Where the earth has been disturbed, either through leveling or clearing, then a sidewalk bed of sand or small gravel not less than three inches in depth shall be placed before the sidewalk cement is poured. 
F.  All sidewalks shall be laid adjacent the street curb, except: 
1.  Where an existing portion of sidewalk already exists within the block on or near the property line, all sidewalks upon that side of the street and within the block where the existing property line sidewalk exists shall be constructed adjacent the property line; 
2.  Where the city council by resolution shall provide otherwise. 
G.  The city manager may authorize the installation of a meandering sidewalk for aesthetic purposes provided said walk does not substantially inconvenience the general public nor create an apparent traffic or pedestrian hazard. 
H.  All cuts or demolition made to existing city sidewalks, or to an adjoining city street, shall be made by concrete or pavement saw cuts and appropriate saw cutting equipment at locations approved by the city manager. Any cuts made to a city curb or city street shall be repaired and repaved in compliance with city street specifications, at the property owner's sole expense. All such repairs to a city street shall be made at the property owner's expense. 
(Ord. 93-1, 1993; Ord. 92-2 § 11, 1992) 
12.12.120 - Driveway approach specifications. 
A.  All driveway approaches and alley approaches hereafter constructed within the city shall be constructed of concrete cement compounded of portland cement, clean sand, clean gravel and water in sufficient quantities to achieve a twenty-eight (28) day compressive strength of at least three thousand (3,000) pounds per square inch when tested in accordance with applicable standards of the American Society for Testing Materials. Concrete shall be poured monolithically and shall be a minimum six-sack mix. Typical dimensions for driveway approaches and alley approaches shall be as set forth in the plans attached to the ordinance codified in this chapter as Exhibit B, which plans are made a part of this chapter. 
B.  Driveway approaches shall be a minimum of fourteen (14) feet in width for a single driveway entrance or twenty (20) feet in width for double entrance within each one hundred (100) feet of property frontage. In no event shall a driveway width extend beyond the property line or lines of the owner of the property wherein the service driveway is installed. Alley approaches shall be constructed so that the width conforms to the width of the alley. 
C.  Driveway portions of sidewalks and alley approaches shall be scribed and finished as in Section 12.12.110(D)(1), and shall be separated from such walks and curbs by a cold joint or one-half inch expansion joint. 
(Ord. 92-2 § 12, 1992) 
12.12.130 - Failure to install-City procedure to install. 
    When a property owner has failed to install or repair a sidewalk as required by any section of this chapter, the city manager shall proceed as follows: 
A.  Submit a report to the city council with a recommendation regarding construction or repair of the sidewalk by the city and set a time and place for a hearing by the city council; 
B.  Send a notice of the hearing to the property owner by regular mail (plain envelope) and certified mail to the address listed on the county tax roll records. Such notice shall: 
1.  Be mailed at least ten (10) working days prior to hearing, 
2.  State the time and place for hearing and specify that the citizen will have opportunity to testify, 
3.  Make reference to the specific violation, 
4.  State the work to be done, 
5.  State the name of the staff member the citizen should contact for details, 
6.  State the specific action the manager is requesting council to take in regard to the property, 
7.  Estimate the cost of installation or repair if city performs the work and state that the estimate is not binding upon the city and merely provided for property owner's information and convenience; 
C.  At the council hearing the council shall: 
1.  Receive the manager's report, staff comments, and the testimony of property owner if said owner desires to testify, 
2.  Deliberate and reach a decision based upon the testimony received, and either approve or deny the request of the manager to install the sidewalk if the property owner has not complied in ten (10) working days or has not made other specific arrangements that are approved by the city manager; 
D.  Notice to property owner of the council's decision shall be given by regular mail (plain envelope) and certified mail and shall contain the following information: 
1.  Council's decision, 
2.  A requirement that action occur within ten (10) working days from the date of notice, 
3.  The opportunity to make arrangements with the city manager for prompt construction or repair of the walk, taking into consideration weather or other work in progress, 
4.  The name of a staff member the citizen may contact for details or with whom other arrangements may be made that satisfy the requirements of this chapter, 
5.  Notice to property owner that if he or she fails to perform, the city will contract to have work done and will add fifteen (15) percent administrative charge to all costs; will charge interest at twelve (12) percent annually; and, in addition, the City will levy an assessment against the property and file a lien in city lien docket with collection upon foreclosure or upon sale of property; 
E.  In the event the owner(s) of the property or properties subject to the above procedure fail(s) to make said improvements or repairs as directed by the council and the city has caused said sidewalk to be installed or repaired, the costs and charges shall become a lien against the adjacent real property. Said lien shall have priority over all other liens against such property, save and except such liens or taxes as by law take precedence, and may be foreclosed in the manner provided by ORS 223.610 or in any other manner provided by law. 
(Ord. 92-2 § 13, 1992) 
(Ord. No. 2009-01, §§ 1, 2, 3-16-2009) 
12.12.140 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.  A person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall: 
1.  Upon the first conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of one hundred eighty dollars ($180.00); 
2.  Upon the second conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred sixty dollars ($360.00); 
3.  Upon the third or further conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of seven hundred twenty dollars ($720.00). 
B.  Each day's violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense, punishable as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. 92-2 § 14, 1992) 
(Ord. No. 2009-01, § 3, 3-16-2009) 
Chapter 12.16 - DRIVEWAY PERMITS 

12.16.010 - Definition. 
    The term "service driveways" as used in this chapter means any driveway entering any street from private property and intended for use and used by the public. 
(Ord. 67-5 § 1, 1967) 
12.16.020 - Permit required. 
    It is unlawful for any person, persons, partnership or corporation to construct or maintain any service driveway in the city without first securing a permit therefor and paying the permit fee required by this chapter. 
(Ord. 67-5 § 2, 1967) 
12.16.030 - Application. 
    Any person, persons, partnership or corporation desiring to obtain a permit for a service driveway, or driveways, to serve property owned, leased, rented or occupied by him or her shall file an application therefor with the city recorder. This application shall be in writing and shall contain information showing the type of construction, the width of the driveway, its exact location, and any other information which may be required by the city council. 
(Ord. 67-5 § 3, 1967) 
12.16.040 - Street superintendent to direct construction and repair. 
    All service driveways shall be constructed and repaired under the direction of the city street superintendent. 
(Ord. 67-5 § 4, 1967) 
12.16.050 - Existing driveways. 
A.  Any person, persons, partnership or corporation now maintaining a service driveway or driveways in the city shall immediately, upon the ordinance codified in this chapter becoming effective, secure a permit to maintain the said service driveway or driveways. 
B.  Any person, persons, partnership or corporation in possession of private property which is served by service driveways shall be considered, for the purpose of this chapter, as maintaining the service driveways to said property. 
(Ord. 67-5 §§ 5 and 6, 1967) 
12.16.060 - Width of driveways. 
A.  Where only one service driveway is requested, the maximum width shall be as follows: frontage twenty (20) to one hundred (100) feet, width twenty (20) feet. 
B.  In no event shall the service driveway extend beyond the property line or lines of the owner of the property wherein the service driveway is requested. 
C.  If more than one service driveway is desired on the same frontage, the maximum width of each driveway shall not exceed twenty (20) feet, and not more than two twenty (20) foot driveways shall be permitted on any given one hundred (100) foot frontage. On any frontage in excess of one hundred (100) feet, each additional one hundred (100) feet, or fraction thereof, shall be considered as under separate ownership. 
(Ord. 67-5 §§ 7 and 8, 1967) 
12.16.070 - Permit fees. 
    The permit fee for each service driveway shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each driveway permit serving residential premises or property and twenty dollars ($20.00) for each driveway permit serving commercial or industrial property. 
(Ord. 88-18, 1988; Ord. 67-5 § 9, 1967) 
12.16.080 - Permit issuance conditions-Revocation. 
    No permit shall be granted unless and until the person, persons, partnership or corporation in possession of the property shall construct and maintain, or cause to be constructed or maintained, that portion of the sidewalk used as a driveway according to the sidewalk specifications of the city, which specifications shall be the minimum requirements. Should the person, persons, partnership or corporation permit the driveway to become dangerous to the public for any reason whatsoever, then the council may revoke any permit outstanding with or without notice to the person, persons, partnership or corporation in possession of the property, and in the event the said driveways are dangerous to the public for any reason whatsoever at the time a permit is applied for, the council may refuse to issue the same. 
(Ord. 67-5 § 10, 1967) 
12.16.090 - Special permits to exceed maximum width. 
    In the event unusual circumstances shall require a driveway exceeding the said twenty (20) foot width, the applicant may apply to the city council stating the reasons for a greater width, and if the council finds that said additional width is necessary, it may grant the applicant a special permit for a driveway exceeding the twenty (20) foot width. 
(Ord. 67-5 § 11, 1967) 
12.16.100 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.  A person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall: 
1.  Upon the first conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00); 
2.  Upon the second conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00); 
3.  Upon the third or further conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. 
B.  Each day's violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense, punishable as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. 88-3 (part), 1988; Ord. 67-5 § 12, 1967) 
Chapter 12.20 - PLACEMENT OF TEMPORARY SIGNS, PLANTERS AND WASTE RECEPTACLES 

12.20.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall mean: 
    "Building frontage" means the portion of a building most closely in alignment with an adjacent street right-of-way. 
    "Freestanding sign" means a sign supported by one or more uprights, poles or braces and placed upon the sidewalk. 
    "Passageway" means the area along the sidewalk reserved for pedestrian and other nonmotorized traffic. For the purposes of this chapter the passageway is five feet in width and extends vertically for eight feet. 
    "Projecting sign" means a sign, the face of which is not parallel to the wall, located on an overhanging eave, awning or other support on which it is mounted. 
    "Sign area" means the entire area within any type of perimeter or border which encloses the outer limits of any writing, representation, emblem, figure or character. If the sign is enclosed in a frame or cabinet, the area is based on the inner dimensions of the frame or cabinet surrounding the sign face. When a sign is on a base material and attached without a frame, such as a wood board or plexiglass panel, the dimensions of the base material are to be used. 
    "Sign face" means the surface of a sign containing the message. The sign face shall be measured as set forth in the definition for "sign area." 
    "Sign height" means the distance from the sidewalk to the top of the sign or the highest portion of the sign structure or frame, whichever is greater. 
    "Sign space" means a two-foot area along the wall of a building, adjacent to a public sidewalk, and extending from the sidewalk to the bottom of an awning, eave or the edge of the roof line (whichever is applicable), and further extending along the entire building frontage. 
    "Sign structure" means the supports, uprights, braces, framework and other structural components of the sign. 
    "Temporary (portable) sign" means a sign not designed to be permanently affixed to a building, structure, or the ground and which may be readily removed. These signs include, but are not limited to, A-frame or sandwich board signs, framed signs, hanging or projecting signs, including those with cloth or canvas banners. 
(Ord. 98-7 § 1, 1998) 
12.20.020 - Location. 
    The placement of the signs, planters or planting boxes, and waste receptacles on public sidewalks shall be limited to those sidewalks located on either side of the following streets: Bridge Street from Yamhill Street to Madison Street; and Main Street from NW Washington Street to NE Hill Street. 
(Ord. 98-7 § 2, 1998) 
12.20.030 - Sign regulations generally. 
    All signs placed within a sidewalk shall be subject to the following limitations: 
A.  Signs shall be limited to temporary (portable) signs as defined by this chapter. 
B.  The sign structure, including sign face and all supporting material, shall be located entirely within the designated sign space as defined by this chapter. 
C.  Signs shall continually maintain a minimum five-foot wide passage between the edge of the sign nearest the curb and the adjacent curb line. 
D.  No more than one temporary (portable) sign shall be placed in front of a business. The placement of said sign shall be reserved and limited solely to the owner/operator of the adjacent business. 
E.  Temporary (portable) signs shall only be displayed during business hours. 
F.  Temporary sign structures shall be constructed of wood, metal or other durable material. 
G.  No sign shall be illuminated, either directly or indirectly, or contain flashing lights. 
H.  Rotating signs shall be prohibited. 
I.  Balloons and other tethered objects shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. 98-7 § 3, 1998) 
12.20.040 - Freestanding signs. 
    In addition to the requirements in Section 12.20.030, freestanding signs shall have a minimum sign height of three feet and a maximum sign height of five feet. 
(Ord. 98-7 § 4, 1998) 
12.20.050 - Projecting signs. 
    In addition to the requirements in Section 12.20.030, projecting temporary signs shall be subject to the following requirements: 
A.  There shall be a minimum eighty (80) inch separation between the sidewalk and any overhead sign support; 
B.  A planter or waste receptacle, complying with the standards in this chapter, shall be placed directly beneath a projecting sign. 
(Ord. 98-7 § 5, 1998) 
12.20.060 - Planters and waste receptacles generally. 
    Planters and waste receptacles may be placed anywhere within a public sidewalk subject to the following restrictions: 
A.  A passageway, as defined by this chapter, shall be maintained between the planter or receptacle and the adjacent curb line or building wall. 
B.  Planters and waste receptacles located adjacent to a curb shall not interfere with an adjacent parking space by restricting access to and from the vehicle. 
(Ord. 98-7 § 6, 1998) 
12.20.070 - Planters. 
    In addition to the requirements in Section 12.20.060, planters shall be subject to the following requirements: 
A.  The minimum planter height shall be sixteen (16) inches, the maximum height shall be thirty-six (36) inches. 
B.  There shall be no limit to the number and length of planters provided the structures comply with location and height restrictions and do not otherwise interfere with pedestrian access to a business. 
C.  Planters shall be constructed of wood or masonry products, such as brick, rock or textured concrete, and shall be continually maintained in a clean and attractive manner. 
D.  Planters shall be continually maintained with flowers, trees, shrubs or other vegetative material. Planters not maintained in such a manner shall be removed from the sidewalk by the owner of the said planter upon direction of the city manager. Holiday displays contained within planters (other than the display of merchandise) shall be permitted. 
E.  Material located within a planter shall not extend into the defined passageway. 
(Ord. 98-7 § 7, 1998) 
12.20.080 - Waste receptacles. 
    In addition to the requirements in Section 12.20.060, waste receptacles shall be subject to the following requirements: 
A.  The minimum height shall be twenty-seven (27) inches, the maximum height shall be four feet. 
B.  No more than one waste receptacle shall be located in front of a business. 
(Ord. 98-7 § 8, 1998) 
12.20.090 - Exemptions. 
    Nothing in these regulations shall prohibit the display and sale of wares during special organizational events and community events pursuant to the requirements contained in Section 9.16.050 of this code. 
(Ord. 98-7 § 9, 1998) 
12.20.100 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.  Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall: 
1.  Upon the first conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00); 
2.  Upon the second conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00); 
3.  Upon a third or further conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. 
B.  Each day's violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense, punishable as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. 98-7 § 10, 1998) 
Chapter 12.24 - PARKS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-01, § 1, adopted February 18, 2014, repealed Ch. 12.24, §§ 12.24.010-12.24.030, and § 2 enacted a new Ch. 12.24, §§ 12.24.010-12.24.030 to read as set out herein. Former Ch. 12.24 pertained to similar subject matter and was derived from Ord. No. 89-15 §§ 1-3, Exh. A, adopted 1989. 

12.24.010 - Rules and regulations established and adopted. 
A.  Rules and regulations for city parks shall be established, maintained and enforced to ensure the orderly, safe and beneficial use of city parks, park lands and public parks and recreation facilities for all persons, and said rules and regulations may, from time to time, be amended by resolution of the city council to maintain such purpose. The rules for specific parks or activities may be augmented, implemented or clarified by administrative order of the city manager to ensure the safe and beneficial use of those facilities. Land not designated as park, such as undeveloped land, open areas, or land surrounding city facilities, are not available for public use. 
B.  Abbreviated rules shall be posted in the parks and all rules will be available at city hall and the public works department. Users of city parks shall abide by such rules and regulations in conjunction with their use of city parks. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 2, 2-18-2014) 
12.24.020 - Rules and regulations for city parks. 
A.  General Rules of Use. 
1.  Disorderly conduct, abusive language, noisy disturbances, use of alcohol or illegal drugs or disregard for park rules and regulations shall result in removal from city parks by authorized city personnel or law enforcement personnel. 
2.  No peddling, soliciting or commercial activities are permitted without prior approval of the city council or its designee. 
3.  Possession or use of intoxicating beverages within any city park or recreation facility is expressly prohibited without obtaining a city permit for such usage. 
4.  Park users shall be liable for damages to park grounds or facilities caused by themselves, their children or pets. 
5.  Children under the age of ten (10) years shall not be left unattended in a city park. 
6.  In all city parks no person other than an authorized peace officer or person licensed pursuant to ORS 166.291 or 166.292, as now or hereafter amended shall carry a firearm, B.B. gun, or air rifle on or about his or her person. No person, other than a peace officer, may carry any knife having a blade that projects or swings into position by force of a spring or by centrifugal force, any knife other than cooking cutlery and pocket knives in the possession of an adult, any dirk, dagger, ice pick, slingshot, metal knuckles, or any similar instrument by the use of which injury could be inflicted upon the person or property of any person. 
B.  Motorized and Other Vehicles. 
1.  Motorized vehicles shall be parked in designated areas only. Vehicles parked in other areas or on grass or turf shall be removed at owner's expense. 
2.  Automotive repairs shall not be permitted anywhere on city park property, including designated parking areas. 
3.  Bicycles, skateboards, roller skates or other nonmotorized vehicles shall be operated in a safe and proper manner and in such a way as to not endanger other park users or damage park property. 
C.  Park Buildings and Facilities. 
1.  Restrooms facilities for public use will be available at some parks from May 1st through October 31st of each year. 
2.  Damage to park property or defacing any park facility shall result in removal from one or more city parks and/or citation by city police. Any activity that causes damage to any park facility is expressly prohibited. 
3.  No pets shall be permitted in any park building, or shelter, or facility. 
4.  All shelters and barbecues shall be cleaned after use. Failure to do so shall result in cleaning at the user's expense and/or refusal of future use. 
5.  Overnight camping is prohibited in city parks. 
6.  Sleeping in any city park is prohibited. 
7.  The city manager and/or the public works director shall establish hours for park use. 
8.  Swimming, wading, or boating in a fishing pond is prohibited. 
9.  Certain park areas may be reserved. City hall shall make any reservations of parks or their facilities. 
D.  Animals. Pets are permitted only if on a leash and under owner's constant control. Pets or other animals allowed to run at large or create a nuisance shall be removed and the owner may be cited. 
E.  Solid Waste Disposal and Fires. 
1.  All garbage and trash must be placed in proper receptacles provided. 
2.  Cooking fires must be contained within pits or grates. Waste disposal fires or uncontained fires of any kind are expressly prohibited. 
F.  Plant Protection. 
1.  Use of trees or shrubs for climbing, swinging, posting notices or as poles for net games is expressly prohibited. 
2.  Any activity that causes damage to trees, grass, flowers or other plants, such as digging, is expressly prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 2, 2-18-2014) 
12.24.025 - Parks exclusion process. 
A.  A person is subject to a warning notice, exclusion from city parks property of properties, immediate ejection from parks property or may otherwise have their city parks privileges restricted or suspended for a period of up to ninety (90) days for any of the following conduct: 
1.  Sleeping. Sleeping using bedding, sleeping bag or other sleeping matter in a city parks unless such use has been approved in advance by the public works director; 
2.  Unrelated Activities. Use of city parks facilities and/or equipment for activities unrelated to the purposes of the city parks; 
3.  Excessive Noise. Loud or excessive noise or use of amplified recording or sound production equipment, including, but not limited to, radios, tape recorders, compact disc (CD) players, and digital media players, such that the sound produced is audible fifteen (15) feet from the device, unless such use has been approved in advance by the parks director; 
4.  Children Required to be in School. Violating ORS 339.010 or any successor statutes, which requires children between the ages of seven and eighteen (18) years who have not completed the 12th grade to attend regularly a public full-time school, unless the child is exempt from compulsory school attendance by ORS 339.030. 
5.  Disruptive Behavior. Disruptive behavior, which includes, but is not limited to: 
a.  Any illegal activity; 
b.  Damaging parks material or equipment; 
c.  Smoking; 
d.  Drinking alcoholic beverages; 
e.  Littering; 
f.  Soliciting; 
g.  Running; 
h.  Harassing patrons and/or staff; 
i.  Using abusive or threatening language or gestures; 
j.  Create public disturbance; 
k.  Panhandling; or 
l.  Riotous behavior. 
6.  Disobeying Parks Staff. Disobeying the direction of a parks staff member. 
7.  Interference with Use or Duties. Persons who interfere with the use of the parks by other persons, or interfere with parks employees' performance of their duties. 
8.  Appropriate Clothing. Persons who are not wearing a shirt or other covering of their upper bodies, pants or other covering of their lower bodies, or who are not wearing shoes or other footwear. 
9.  Hygiene. Persons whose bodily hygiene is offensive so as to constitute a nuisance to other persons shall be required to leave the park. 
10.  Weapons. Persons who bring a weapon into a city park unless authorized by law under ORS 166.370. 
11.  Animals. Allowing any non-service animal that is not pre-approved by parks staff into the park. Any service animal that is allowed to annoy, molest, bark continuously, attack or injure any person or animal on park property or is tied up and left unattended will no longer be deemed a service animal and will not be permitted to remain on the premises. Service animals must be harnessed, leashed, or tethered, unless these devices interfere with the service animals' work or the individual's disability prevents using these devices. In that case, the individual must maintain control of the animal through voice, signal, or other effective controls. 
Under the federal Americans with Disabilities Act, a service animal is defined as a dog that is individually trained to do work or perform tasks for people with disabilities. The work or task the animal has been trained to provide must be directly related to the person's disability. A service animal whose sole function is to provide comfort or emotional support do not qualify as service animal under the ADA. 
A miniature horse that has been individually trained to do work or perform tasks for people [with] disabilities will be considered a service animal. Miniature horses generally range in height from twenty-four (24) to thirty-four (34) inches measured to the shoulders and generally weigh between seventy (70) to one hundred (100) pounds. Entry into a park will be permitted where reasonable. There are four assessment factors which are: 
(1)  Whether the miniature horse is housebroken; 
(2)  Whether the miniature horse is under the owner's control; 
(3)  Whether the facility can accommodate the miniature horse's type, size, and weight; and 
(4)  Whether the miniature horse's presence will not compromise legitimate safety requirements necessary for safe operation of the facility. 
B.  As used in subsection (A), the term "parks privileges" means the ability to enter a city park or make any use of any city park facilities. 
C.  A person may be immediately ejected form [from] a city park or all city parks based on conduct from subsection (A), at the discretion of the public works director or other authorized designee. 
(Ord. No. 2014-02, § 1, 2-18-2014) 
12.24.026 - Persons authorized to issue exclusion or warning notices or eject individuals from city parks. 
    The public works director is hereby designated as the person in charge of city parks for purposes of excluding or ejecting individuals and issuing exclusion or warning notices in accordance with this chapter. The public works director may authorize other personnel to exclude or eject individuals or issue exclusion or warning notices consistent with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2014-02, § 1, 2-18-2014) 
12.24.027 - Issuance of warnings or exclusion notices. 
A.  Warning Notice. At the time of the occurrence of any conduct identified in Section 12.24.025(A), the public works director, or designee may issue a written warning notice. The notice shall specify that in the event a second notice is issued to the individual within ninety (90) days of the first notice, that person shall be subject to exclusion from the parks or all city parks and/or lose such other parks privileges as the public works director may determine to be appropriate for a period of up to ninety (90) days. The warning notice shall include information concerning the right to appeal the warning notice to the city manager. 
B.  Exclusion Notice. The public works director may issue a written exclusion notice excluding the person from one or more city parks. If an individual engages in conduct described in Section 12.24.025(A) above that warrants exclusion without a warning notice, then the individual will receive a written exclusion notice. 
The notice shall specify that the person is to be excluded from the park or parks, the period of the exclusion, the time the exclusion is to commence, as well as contain information concerning the right to appeal the exclusion notice to the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 2014-02, § 1, 2-18-2014) 
12.24.028 - Right to appeal. 
A.  The individual who is excluded, to whom a warning or exclusion notice is issued, or to whom a permit application has been denied shall have the right to appeal the decision. 
B.  An appeal must be filed, in writing, with the city manager within five business days of the notice's issuance. The notice of appeal shall state the following: 
1.  The appellant's name; 
2.  The appellant's address and a telephone number where they can be reached. 
3.  A concise statement as to why the exclusion, denial of a permit or issuance of the notice was in error; and 
4.  Attach a copy of the notice or letter of denial. 
C.  A hearing on the appeal shall be held no more than thirty (30) calendar days after the filing of the appeal, except in the event the city manager determines otherwise. The hearing shall afford a reasonable opportunity for the person requesting it to present and rebut evidence that the warning, exclusion, or permit denial is invalid or unjustified. The decision of the city manager is final and shall be in writing. The written decision shall state how it can be appealed. 
D.  The warning or exclusion shall remain in effect during the pendency of the appeal. 
E.  The city shall have the burden to show by a preponderance of evidence that the warning or exclusion is based on conduct described in Section 12.24.025. 
F.  Copies of any and all city documents used by the city at the hearing shall be made available to the appellant upon request. 
(Ord. No. 2014-02, § 1, 2-18-2014) 
12.24.030 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.  A person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall: 
1.  Upon the first conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of one hundred eighty dollars ($180.00); 
2.  Upon the second conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred sixty dollars ($360.00); 
3.  Upon a third or further conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of seven hundred twenty dollars ($720.00). 
B.  Each day's violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense, punishable as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 2, 2-18-2014) 
Title 13 - PUBLIC SERVICES 
Chapter 13.04 - WATER SERVICE SYSTEM 
Article I. - General Provisions 

13.04.010 - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known as "rules and regulations for the operation of the Sheridan water system." 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 1 § 1, 1986) 
13.04.020 - Scope. 
    The city and all customers receiving service from the water system, whether inside or outside the city limits, are bound by these rules and regulations. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 1 § 2, 1986) 
13.04.030 - Definitions. 
    When used in this chapter, these words shall mean the following: 
    "Abandoned premise" means a building or facility which the owner, known or unknown, has forsaken, deserted, or given up on usually evidenced by failure to pay utilities, taxes or other valid charges. 
    "Applicant" means the person or persons, firm or corporation making application for water service from the water system under the terms of these regulations. 
    "City" means the legally constituted municipal government of the city of Sheridan. 
    "Customer" means an applicant who has been accepted under the terms of these regulations and who receives service from the water system. 
    "Customer hand valve" means a valve or control installed on the customer's service line by means of which the delivery of water to the premises may be turned off. 
    "Customer service line" means that part of the piping on the customer's property that connects the service to the customer's distribution system. 
    "Destroyed premise" means a building or facility which has been made unusable or uninhabitable by either manmade activities or an act of God. 
    "Disconnection," or "turned off," is the separation of the water supply to the property. It is usually done by turning of the city's water supply to the property, locking off the supply or removing the water meter or a pipe that leads to the property. 
    "Discontinuance" is the termination of the city's water supply to the property or facility. It is usually done by either the property owner or the city removing the pipes, or other conveyances, that are on the property to ensure that the facility or property cannot use the water system. 
    "Noncommunity public water system" means a system for the provision to the public of piped water for human consumption, which system has more than three service connections used by year-round residents, or regularly serves more than three customers from a single metered service owned by the city. 
    "Premises" means the integral property or area, including improvements thereon, to which water service is or will be provided. 
    "Regular service" is when water service and meter is provided to a building or facility for use in accordance with the established or permitted use of the property. 
    "Service connection" means that part of the water distribution system which connects the meter to the main and which normally consists of a corporation stop, service pipe, curb stop and box, meter, meter yoke and meter box. 
    "Superintendent" means the city manager, or his or her authorized deputy, agent or representative, or the person appointed by the city council to manage the affairs of the water system. 
    "Systems development charge" means that charge, as determined by the city council, assessed to defray the cost of providing, extending, maintaining or replacing water system supply, treatment or distribution capacity to serve the customers of the water system. Systems development charge shall not include any additional charges which may be required to obtain a building permit or compensate the city for costs of physically connecting to the water system. 
    "Temporary service" is the installation of water service and meter for building or construction services only. 
    "Water system" means all city-owned facilities for supply, transmission, storage, treatment and distribution of potable water. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 1 § 3, 1986) 
(Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 1-17-2012; Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, 3-19-2012) 
Article II. - Administration and Enforcement 

13.04.040 - Access to property. 
    All duly appointed employees of the city, under direction of the city superintendent, shall have free access at all reasonable hours of the day to any and all parts of structures and premises to which water is or may be delivered, for the purpose of inspecting connections and examining conduits and fixtures of the city water system. The city does not, however, assume the duty of inspecting the customer's lines, plumbing or equipment and shall not be responsible therefor. The customer must keep vicious dogs or other animals secured or confined to avoid interference with utility operation and maintenance. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 12 § 1, 1986) 
13.04.050 - Responsibility for city equipment. 
    City equipment on the customer's premises remains the property of the city and may be repaired, replaced or removed by authorized city employees at any time without the consent of the customer. No payment shall be made to the customer for the right to install, maintain, replace or remove city equipment on the premises. The customer must exercise reasonable care to prevent damage to equipment and must in no way interfere with its operation. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 12 § 2, 1986) 
13.04.060 - Responsibility for customer equipment. 
A.  The city shall not be liable for any loss or damage of any nature whatsoever caused by any defect in the customer's lines, plumbing or equipment, nor shall the city be liable for loss or damage due to interruption of service or temporary changes in water pressure. 
B.  The customer shall be responsible for valves on the premises being turned off when the water service is turned on. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 12 § 3, 1986) 
13.04.070 - Liability for interruptions in service. 
    The city shall not be liable for damage resulting from the interruption of service or from a lack of service. Temporary suspension of service by the city for improvements and repairs will be necessary occasionally. Whenever possible, and when time permits, all customers affected will be notified prior to shut downs. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 12 § 4, 1986) 
13.04.080 - Damage to city equipment. 
    The customer shall be liable for any damage to equipment owned by the city caused by an act (or negligent omission) of the customer or his or her tenants. Damage to equipment shall include, but not be limited to, breaking of seals and locks, tampering with meters or hydrants, and injury to meters or appurtenances, including but not limited to damages caused by hot water, steam, or freezing temperatures. The city shall be reimbursed by the customer for the actual cost of repair or replacement, plus fifteen (15) percent for administrative cost and overhead. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 12 § 5, 1986) 
13.04.090 - Unsafe apparatus-Inspection. 
A.  The city may refuse to furnish water and may discontinue service to a premises where an apparatus, appliance or other equipment using water is dangerous, unsafe or is being used in violation of laws, ordinances or legal regulations. 
B.  The city does not assume liability for inspecting apparatus on the customer's premises. The city does reserve the right of inspection if there is reason to believe that unsafe or illegal apparatus is in use. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 12 § 6, 1986) 
13.04.100 - Water waste. 
    Where wasteful or negligent water use seriously affects the general service, the city may discontinue the service if such conditions are not corrected within five days after the customer is given written notice by the city. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 12 § 7, 1986) 
13.04.110 - Service detrimental to others. 
    The city may refuse to furnish water and may discontinue service to premises where excessive demand by one customer will result in inadequate service to others. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 12 § 8, 1986) 
13.04.120 - Fraud and abuse. 
    The city shall have the right to refuse or to discontinue water service to a premises to protect itself against fraud and abuse. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 12 § 9, 1986) 
13.04.130 - Abandoned and non-revenue producing services. 
    Where a premises to which water service is provided is demolished, destroyed or abandoned, the city may remove the meter and service connection. New service shall be placed only upon the customer's application therefor and payment of the installation charge. If a new service size is larger than the previous service, or if the period of abandonment exceeds twelve (12) consecutive months, the customer shall also pay a connection charge. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 12 § 10, 1986) 
13.04.140 - Fluoridation of water. 
A.  It appears to the council of the city that it is for the best interests of the citizens of said city that the domestic water supply of the city be treated with fluoride according to accepted scientific practices for the fluoridation of drinking water. 
B.  The city water department is directed to fluoridate the domestic water supply of the city, by connecting to the main intake line of said system an automatic fluoride dispenser to inject fluoride into said water system at the rate of one part per million (1,000,000) gallons of water or the rates as set by federal and/or state authorities. 
C.  For the purpose of complying with this section the water department of the city is directed to purchase an automatic fluoride dispenser, suitable for such purpose. 
(Ord. F-1000 §§ 1-3, 1965) 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, 3-19-2012) 
13.04.150 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.  A person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall: 
1.  Upon the first conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of one hundred eighty dollars ($180.00); 
2.  Upon the second conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred sixty dollars ($360.00); 
3.  Upon the third or further conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed the sum of seven hundred twenty dollars ($720.00). 
B.  Each day's violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense, punishable as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. 88-3 (part), 1988; Ord. 86-1 Art. 12 § 11, 1986) 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, 3-19-2012) 
Article III. - Service Connection and Meter Installation 

13.04.160 - Application form. 
    Each applicant for water service shall sign an application form provided by the city, giving date of application, location of premises, whether they have been served before, date the applicant desires service to begin, purposes for which service is to be used, the address for mailing or delivery of bills, the applicant's address, whether owner, tenant or agent, the size of service requested, and such other information as the city may reasonably require. In signing the application, the applicant agrees to abide by the regulations of the city water system. The application is merely a written request for service and does not bind the city to approve the application for service. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 2 § 1, 1986) 
13.04.170 - Establishment of credit-Deposit. 
A.  Establishment of Credit. At the time application for service is made, the applicant shall establish his or her credit with the city. The applicant will be classified as a property owner, owner's manager, or tenant. Government facilities and non-profits, including houses of worship shall be considered property owners. The credit of the applicant will be deemed established if: 
1.  Property Owners/Property Managers. 
a.  A utility deposit of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) is received; and 
b.  There are no delinquent municipal utility accounts in the name of the applicant or any entity owned by the applicant. Any delinquent account shall be paid in the amount of the delinquency plus any other required charges which may be assessed prior to the restoration of water and approval of credit. 
2.  Tenants. 
a.  A utility deposit of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) is received; and. 
b.  There are no delinquent municipal utility accounts in the name of the tenant. Any delinquent account shall be paid in the amount of the delinquency plus any other required charges which may be assessed prior to the restoration of water and approval of credit. 
B.  Deposit. At the time the deposit is given to the city, the applicant shall be given a receipt for same. The deposit is not to be considered a payment on account. Deposits for tenant customers will be returned when they terminate service within the city provided all outstanding bills have been paid. The deposit for property owners will be returned to the owner when service is discontinued, provided all outstanding bills have been paid. The city will return the property owner's deposit, without application, provided all bills have been paid in a timely manner for twenty-four (24) months. 
C.  Reconnection Fee. If an account becomes delinquent and it is necessary to turn off water service, service shall not be restored to a customer at the same or different premises until the entire outstanding balance, including the fifty dollar ($50.00) reconnection fee, has been paid. 
D.  Water Shut Off for Nonpayment Twice within a Calendar Year. If an account becomes delinquent and it is necessary to turn off service for a second or additional time within a calendar year, a deposit balance of one hundred seventy-five dollars ($175.00) will be required prior to restoration of service. The same policy shall apply to accounts where two or more NSF checks have been presented for payment within a calendar year. 
E.  The full amount of charges incurred by the city for checks returned to the city for non-sufficient funds ("NSF") shall be charged to the appropriate utility accounts held by such utility customer with the city. 
(Ord. 03-13 § 1, 2003: Ord. 00-7 § 1, 2000: Ord. 86-1 Art. 2 §§ 2-4, 1986) 
(Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 1-17-2012; Res. No. 2014-J, § 1, 8-4-2014) 
13.04.180 - Application approval-Commencement of service connection. 
A.  Upon approval of an application for water service and payment of all required charges, the city will install a service connection and meter of such size and location as approved by the city superintendent. 
B.  Where the service connection and meter have been installed, regular service shall be provided upon application and payment of all charges if the structure for which service is desired complies with subsection C of this section. 
C.  Regular service shall not be provided until the structure to which water is furnished has received a final building inspection or a temporary or permanent certificate of occupancy, as appropriate to the structure. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 3 § 1, 1986) 
13.04.190 - Payment of fees and charges and connection permit required. 
    No person, applicant or agent shall connect any building or structure to the city water system unless and until the charges and fees authorized in Sections 13.04.170 and 13.04.180 have been paid and a connection permit issued. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 7 § 3, 1986) 
13.04.200 - Service connections. 
A.  All domestic service connections shall include the installation or construction of an approved meter box, water meter and other appurtenances, and connection from the water main to the nearest property line, or the street side of a sidewalk, or other location appropriate under the circumstances, all as determined by the city superintendent. 
B.  No service connection of less than three-quarter inch in size shall be installed. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 7 §§ 1 and 2, 1986) 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, 3-19-2012) 
13.04.210 - City to own service connection. 
    The service connection, whether located on public or private property, is the property of the city, and the city reserves the right to repair, maintain or replace it. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 3 § 5, 1986) 
13.04.220 - Meters. 
A.  Purpose and Policy. In order to provide for the equitable distribution of water by the city, water meters are to be installed on all private customer connections to the city water system. Meters shall be installed in such order or sequence as the city council shall determine. 
B.  Ownership. The city shall own and maintain all water meters. The city shall not pay rent or any other charge for a meter or other equipment, including housing and connections, whether located on public or private property. 
C.  Installation. Installation of water meters shall be performed only by authorized employees of the city, except as specifically provided or required by this chapter. All meters shall be sealed by the city at the time of installation and no seal shall be altered or broken except by one of its authorized employees. 
D.  Size and Type of Meter. The city expressly reserves the right to determine the size and type of meter to be installed, including any appurtenances associated with metered delivery of water service. 
E.  Joint Use of Meters. The joining of several customers shall be prohibited except under written agreement approved by the city or as provided in Section 13.04.440. 
F.  Changes in Size or Location. If, for any reason, a change in size or location of a meter or service is required by the customer or property owner, the customer's water service application shall be amended and charges, including system development charges, for a new service shall be assessed. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 10 §§ 1-6, 1986) 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, 3-19-2012) 
13.04.230 - Turning on water without authority. 
    If service to the premises is turned on without authority from the city superintendent, the service shall, if a material amount of water is consumed, be terminated and the meter removed, or locked off, by the city. Water services turned on without authority will be charged a fifty dollar ($50.00) reconnection fee for each instance of unauthorized reconnection. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 2 § 6, 1986) 
(Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 1-17-2012) 
13.04.240 - Customer control valve. 
    Customers shall install and maintain a hand-operated control valve in the customer service line as close to the meter as possible, the operation of which will control the entire water supply to the premises served. It shall be a violation of these rules and regulations for the customer to operate or cause unauthorized operation of the meter stop or any other appurtenances on the service connection. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 3 § 4, 1986) 
13.04.250 - Compliance with plumbing code required. 
    The customer's plumbing, which shall include the customer's service line and all plumbing, piping, fixtures and other appurtenances carrying or intended to carry water, sewage or drainage, shall comply with the plumbing code of the state of Oregon. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 3 § 2, 1986) 
13.04.260 - Customer obligations. 
    The customer shall, at his or her own risk and expense, furnish, install and keep in good and safe condition such equipment that may be required for receiving, controlling, applying and utilizing water. The city shall not be responsible for loss or damage caused by the improper care or wrongful act of the customer or his or her agent in installing, maintaining, using, operating or interfering with such equipment. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 3 § 3, 1986) 
13.04.270 - Request for change in service. 
    Customers desiring a material change in the size, character or extent of equipment or operation which would result in a material change in the amount of water used shall give the city written notice of such change prior to the change and the application for service shall be amended. Customers desiring a change in the location or number of services shall fill out an amended application. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 2 § 5, 1986) 
Article IV. - Water Services and Charges 

13.04.280 - Assessment of user rates, fees and charges. 
A.  User rates for service shall be assessed monthly and shall cover the cost of system operation, maintenance, debt retirement and capital replacement. Rates shall be assessed and charged according to each user's metered consumption. 
B.  The city council may, by ordinance, establish and modify the fees, rates and charges which are collected for water service delivered by the city water system. A copy of any such ordinance, as adopted and currently in effect, shall be codified in Article VI of this chapter, and shall be attached to a copy of the ordinance codified in this chapter which is made available for public inspection at City Hall. 
C.  Fees and charges for issuance of a permit to install a service connection shall include the cost of all labor, equipment and materials necessary for said installation, plus a systems development charge. The city council shall set the amount of such charges in the manner provided by subsection B of this section. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 8 §§ 1-3, 1986) 
13.04.290 - Service charges and billing. 
A.  The city shall establish and maintain a billing account for every customer receiving water service. A separate deposit account shall be established and maintained where the customer's credit must be established as provided in Section 13.04.170. 
B.  Water service will be billed at regular intervals and payment shall be made within the first ten (10) days of the month following the month in which the billing period ends. 
C.  All water service charges shall be mailed to the premises where water is furnished unless the property owner requests in writing that the bill be submitted to another address. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 9 §§ 1, 2, 6 and 15, 1986) 
(Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 1-17-2012) 
13.04.300 - Meter readings. 
A.  Meters will be read at regular intervals for the preparation of regular bills and as required for the preparation of opening, closing and special billings. 
B.  Each meter on a customer's premises shall be billed separately, and the readings of two or more meters shall not be combined unless the city's convenience so requires. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 9 §§ 3 and 5, 1986) 
13.04.310 - Failure to read meters. 
    In the event that it shall be impossible or impractical to read a meter on the regular reading date, the water consumption from the previous month shall be pro-rated on the basis of thirty (30) days per month and the total consumption for that period may be estimated, by the billing department or the city superintendent, for billing purposes. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 10 § 9, 1986) 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, 3-19-2012) 
13.04.320 - Nonregistering meters. 
    In the event a meter is determined to be nonregistering, the customer's account charges will be estimated by the billing department or the city superintendent, and the meter will be replaced by the city. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 10 § 8, 1986) 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, 3-19-2012) 
13.04.330 - Meter error and testing. 
A.  No meter will be placed in service or allowed to remain in service which is known to have an error in registration in excess of three percent under normal operating conditions. 
B.  The city may, at its option, test any meter for accuracy of registration. No charge for meter testing will be made to the customer for the test when it is performed at the city's option. If the test reveals an error of registration which results in an overcharge to the customer, his or her account may be credited accordingly for a period not to exceed three billing periods. The customer's account shall not be debited for an undercharge due to meter error when the meter is tested as provided in this section. 
C.  In the event of a customer complaint that the user charge for any particular billing period is excessive, the city will have the meter re-read and the service inspected for leaks. At the customer's request, the city will test meter accuracy upon deposit by the customer of the amount set by ordinance of the city council necessary to defray the cost of meter testing. The meter will then be tested. If the test reveals a registration in excess of three percent in favor of the city, the amount deposited shall be refunded and the customer's account credited accordingly. If the test reveals a registration in excess of three percent in favor of the customer, the amount of the deposit shall be applied to the account and any remaining balance refunded. If no error in registration is found, the deposit shall be retained to defray the expense of the meter test. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 10 § 7, 1986) 
13.04.340 - Delinquent accounts. 
A.  Upon failure to pay water charges when due, the account shall be delinquent and the water service to the customer may be turned off. 
B.  Prior to turning off water for delinquency, the city shall advise the water bill recipient (and property owner or manager if the customer is a tenant) that water service will be disconnected unless the delinquent amount is paid within five calendar days from date of notice, by four p.m. Notice shall be sent by first class mail. If full payment is not made in the time so specified, the city shall turn off water service to the customer. 
C.  The customer owing a delinquent charge shall pay the amount of delinquency plus any other required charges which may be assessed prior to restoration of water service by the city. 
(Ord. 99-3 § 1, 1999; Ord. 86-1 Art. 9 §§ 7-9, 1986) 
(Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 1-17-2012) 
13.04.350 - Responsibility for payment. 
    The property owner of record shall be responsible for payment of all charges prescribed in this chapter. If the property is rented and the renter fails to pay the charges, the city shall submit the bill to the property owner. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 9 § 10, 1986) 
13.04.360 - Unpaid charges constitutes lien. 
    Water service charges shall be a lien against the premises served from and after the date of billing and entry on the ledger of accounts pertaining to the city water system. Such ledger of accounts shall be made available for inspection to anyone interested in ascertaining the amount of such charges. Whenever a bill for water service remains unpaid for ninety (90) days after it has been rendered, the lien thereby created may be foreclosed in the manner provided by ORS 223.610, or in any manner provided by law or ordinance of the city. Any lien created pursuant to this section shall have priority over any other encumbrance against said premises, including encumbrances created and recorded prior to the date such lien shall be created. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 9 § 11, 1986) 
13.04.370 - Disconnection of service. 
A.  A customer may have his or her water service disconnected by notifying the city of the desired date of disconnection. The customer shall be required to pay water charges until the date of disconnection. 
B.  If notice is not given, the customer shall be required to pay for service until the date the city has learned that the customer has vacated the premises and the city has disconnected service. 
C.  Closing bills shall be paid at the time service is discontinued. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 9 §§ 4, 12 and 13, 1986) 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, 3-19-2012) 
13.04.380 - Discontinuation of service for noncompliance with regulations. 
    The city may discontinue water service to a customer for noncompliance with a water regulation if the customer fails to comply with the regulation within five days after receiving written notice of the city's intention to discontinue service. If such noncompliance affects matters of health or safety or to other conditions which warrant such action, the city may discontinue water service immediately. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 9 § 14, 1986) 
13.04.390 - Resale of water. 
    No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the city water supply to any premises or person other than the premises or person to which the service is provided unless the water is further processed or part of a process in a commercial or industrial facility in accordance with applicable laws, rules, and regulations. A violation of this section shall be grounds for disconnection or discontinuance of water service. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 3 § 6, 1986) 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, 3-19-2012) 
13.04.400 - Service interruptions. 
    The water may be shut off from the mains without notice for repairs and other necessary purposes, and the city will not be responsible for any consequent damages; but whenever it is practical in such cases, the city superintendent shall give at least twelve (12) hours' notice before water is shut off from the mains. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 3 § 7, 1986) 
13.04.410 - Leakage on customer's line. 
    Where a leak exists underground between the meter and a building (usually the house or first structure that receives water) and the same is repaired within ten (10) days after the owner, tenant or agent of the premises has been notified of such leakage, or has knowledge of the same, the customer's account may be credited by the billing department for fifty (50) percent of the estimated consumption based upon a floating average of past usage. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 3 § 8, 1986) 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, 3-19-2012) 
13.04.420 - Temporary service. 
A.  Provision of Temporary Service. A builder or property owner may request installation of temporary service and meter to supply water for building or construction purposes. Such temporary service will be provided upon application therefor and payment of all charges. 
B  Charges. Charges for water furnished through a temporary connection shall be at the appropriate established rates for water service. 
C.  Damages. The person requesting temporary service shall be responsible for all damages that occur to the service, meter or meter box, including damage which arises from freezing temperatures or the conduct of building or construction activity. 
D.  Conversion to Regular Service. It shall be the responsibility of the temporary water user to inform any subsequent occupant of the premises that the service is temporary and may be terminated until a final inspection has been performed and application for regular service is made with the city. 
(Ord. 86-1 Art. 4 §§ 1-4, 1986) 
13.04.430 - Service outside city limits. 
A.  Water service to customers outside the city limits shall at all times be subject to the prior and superior rights of customers inside the city limits. 
B.  Applicants for water service outside the city boundaries shall execute a form containing the following agreement: 
 Application is hereby made for water service at premises known as _____, outside the city of Sheridan, Oregon. 
 It is understood and agreed that if this service is allowed, the undersigned owner or occupant of the premises referred to herein shall pay the rate prescribed by the city of Sheridan from time to time for service at that location; that this service shall be a special contract service and not provided by the city as a common utility service; that the quantity of water supplied by the service may be reduced, or the service entirely discontinued, at any time when the city council of said city finds such action necessary in order to provide sufficient service to the inhabitants within the limits of said city, inasmuch as water service beyond the city limits is a service of surplus water and not needed within the city; that at least 30 days' written notice shall be given by the city before such discontinuance may be put into effect; that notice delivered at the premises or at the last known address of the owner or applicant shall be sufficient; provided, however, the city council may declare an emergency exists and the water may be shut off without said notice. 
 That the undersigned owner may discontinue service without advance notice of more than one day, but shall be responsible for all water served to the premises by the city until such notice in writing is given of such discontinuance. 
C.  Rates for purchase of water by customers outside the city shall be established by the city council based on but not limited to the following considerations: 
1.  The cost of operation and maintenance of the affected capital improvements, prorated on demand estimated by the city; 
2.  The depreciated value of affected capital improvements; and 
3.  A rate of return on the investment for capital improvements serving the area(s) outside the city, which rate shall not be less than ten (10) percent. 
D.  Provision of services of the city water system shall be further governed by applicable policies, as duly adopted or amended, contained in the city of Sheridan comprehensive land use plan and city ordinances which implement the plan. 
E.  The owner of the tract of land outside the city shall make written application on approved forms to the city council of Sheridan for new water service and submit as a part of such application a plot or map of the area and improvements proposed to be served. 
F.  Water service, if approved, will be only to an agreed upon area and residence, designated on the plot or map submitted to the council. Service to an unapproved residence or area would be cause for the city council to give notice of disconnection or discontinuance and effect termination of service. 
G.  The area to be served will agree to annexation to the city at the option of the city under then existing laws pertaining to annexation in the state of Oregon. 
H.  The water service may be discontinued to any customer under this policy in accordance with the city policies concerning the sale of surplus water. 
I.  The owner shall be responsible for the construction and maintenance of his/her/its' own service line to the water transmission line, all at his/her/its' sole cost and expense, and he shall pay all applicable system development, hookup, inspection and meter fees and charges. 
J.  Construction and installation of such service line must have prior written approval by the city council of the city of Sheridan, Oregon. 
K.  The owner shall enter into a written contract for the purchase of outside water on the contract form and subject to terms and conditions approved by the city council. 
L.  In connection with normal operations or emergency situations on the transmission line, the city shall reserve the right to suspend service for repairs, maintenance, or reconstruction. 
M.  Due to changes or increase in the city's demand for water through said transmission mainline, the city council shall make no guarantee as to a sustained water pressure in said mainline. The outside user shall be responsible for installation of supplemental pumps or storage necessary to maintain adequate and lawful pressure to the outside water user. 
N.  Although the city's water supply is and will be, for the foreseeable future, chlorine-treated at the city's water treatment plant, in the event the city's treatment facilities are moved to a location at or near the city of Sheridan, Oregon, then it will become necessary for the owner to treat the water he receives from the city's transmission line, and the city will give the owner one year's written notice of the change of location of its treatment facility. 
O.  The applicant's approval is valid for service to one residence, or specified improvements only. 
P.  City water service district boundaries are the corporate limits of the city. 
Q.  Water service connections beyond the service district boundaries will be granted only when the following criteria are met to the sole satisfaction of the city council: 
1.  The service interest is in the best interest of the city. 
2.  The service connection will not result in a substantially greater density or intensity of use than has been existing on the proposed site. 
3.  The property owner signs a petition requesting annexation or waiving objection to any future annexation of the property to the city, binding upon heirs/assigns, or successors in interest, and this document is recorded against the property. 
4.  The service shall be exclusive to one use and may not be utilized to serve another residence, business or firm. At the time that the service agreement is executed, the use will be enumerated and limited thereby, except for accessory uses and structures. 
5.  The service connection will continue only so long or at such times as it can be maintained without jeopardizing the supply to the city. 
6.  The service connection and all costs associated with extending the service to the property shall be born by the recipient. All such extensions shall be built and maintained to city public works standards at the recipient's expense. 
7.  The service connection shall meet all Yamhill County building and zoning requirements. 
8.  For water services within the urban growth boundary: the service connection replaces an existing water supply that does not meet Oregon Health Division Safe Drinking Water Standards. 
9.  For water services outside the urban growth boundary: the service connection replaces an existing water supply which constitutes a health hazard. In situations where circumstances make the cost of an alternative water source prohibitive, additional service may be granted to existing dwellings along the mainline extension. 
10.  The applicant made and documented reasonable efforts to obtain an alternative source of potable domestic water, and failed to secure such water supplies despite such best efforts. 
R.  Notwithstanding the foregoing criteria, the city reserves the right to grant access to city water service to properties located outside the city municipal boundaries in exchange for easement or other property rights beneficial to the city. 
(Ord. 02-9 § 1, 2002; Ord. 86-1 Art. 5 §§ 1-4, 1986) 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, 3-19-2012) 
13.04.440 - Special services. 
A.  Contracted Services.
